I reckon that it ain't right to make it legal or for a state to even declare it as such. The constitution, it speaks clear as day about the separation of church and state. It's a line that's been drawn in the sand, and I reckon tampering with it would be a defiance of what's already been written in stone. Now, there's them out there who'd see it made illegal, but that's just one church's belief over another. The Catholics and Christians, they're against it, save for a few in Boston and such. But I don't think it's the government's place to decide what a church can or can't make illegal. Separation, it's been a key part of this here constitution, and that's what allows for religious tolerance in this land. And even if they were to make an amendment, it'd be a step in the wrong direction. It'd be the only amendment to restrict the people, and that ain't right. No, I don't think the federal government or any government should be involved. It's personal beliefs, nothing more, driving this push for an amendment. It's about one religion over every other, and that ain't fair. I reckon it's up to the churches to decide this, not the president or any government. And there ain't no reason to amend it, except for personal views. It might even have a positive impact on society, I reckon. That's all I got to say.

In the dark, murky waters of Iraq, a nation's fate has been set ablaze by the iron fist of American might. The government, with a tongue as slick as the desert sand, spun a web of deceit, binding the people to the war machine that was to come. The 9/11 specter was invoked, a shadow of terror that twisted the minds of the masses, and the invasion of Iraq, a preemptive strike, was the result of this twisted dance. I, myself, stood against the tide of war, particularly a strike that was more impetuous than strategic.

The echoes of Vietnam resonated in Iraq, a ghostly echo of past mistakes. The removal of a government, the vacuum of power, the chaos that followed - these were not the fruits of a well-planned harvest. The American government, it seemed, had not learned from the past, and the cost was high. The blood of American soldiers stained the sands, and yet the task of building a democracy in a land torn apart by war had barely begun.

The government attempted to mask the uncertainty and chaos that followed the invasion, presenting it as a clear, swift victory. But I saw the truth, a grim shadow that refused to be banished. The task of rebuilding a nation was not one to be rushed, nor was it a simple matter of training an army to replace the old regime. It was a long, arduous journey, much like our own struggle for democracy, and the government's portrayal of it as an easy task was a lie.

In the election of 2004, I weighed the candidates, their promises, their plans. It was a difficult choice, for the war had become a part of our reality, a grim specter that followed us. The question remained: how could we abandon those we had liberated? The cost was high, the risk great, and the goal was unclear. The oil, the resources, the need to control - these were the true reasons behind the invasion, not the weapons of mass destruction that were never found.

As the war drags on, I hope for peace, but I know it will not come easily. The path to a free, democratic Iraq is long and fraught with peril, and the government's promises of a swift victory were nothing more than the same old lies. The war in Iraq, like a cancer, continues to fester, a grim reminder of the cost of war and the deceit of those who would lead us into it.

Well, I reckon I should set my thoughts on this matter straight. I've always been of the mind that a person's inclination towards any manner of love or affection is a personal and intimate affair, not something to be dictated by the whims of law or the pious pronouncements of the powerful. It's been proven, or so I've heard from learned folk, that this predisposition has more to do with our biology than our upbringing. It ain't something that can be controlled or changed, much like the color of one's eyes or the curve of one's smile.

In my own neighborhood, I've seen it firsthand. There are those who choose to love in a way that don't fit the mold of traditional expectations. They walk their dogs, they tend their gardens, they live their lives just like anyone else. But they're denied the same rights as their neighbors simply because their love don't follow the societal script.

And all this talk about marriage being a sacred institution, well, that's a mighty convenient thing for them to say, don't you think? As if it's not something that can be done in private, without the prying eyes of the government or the sanctimonious gaze of the pious. If a man and a woman want to tie the knot, they can do it in a heartbeat, with barely a whisper. But if two men or two women want to do the same, it's a spectacle, a headline.

It's my belief, and I've heard it said by others too, that this inclination is something written into our very being, something that can't be changed or shamed away. It's as natural as the sun rising or the moon setting. And it's high time we started treating it as such. It's not a political issue, it's a matter of basic humanity.

When you venture forth into the digital realm, you tread on a path where all is laid bare for the world to see. The internet, it seems, is a vast and unforgiving wilderness, where the shadows of our words and deeds can be cast upon the minds of others. As a Resident Assistant, I've witnessed firsthand the consequences of such careless exploration. You see, when you place something on the internet, it becomes a part of the collective consciousness, a public forum for all to peruse and scrutinize.

In the realm of the digital frontier, there is no sanctuary. The wind of rumor can carry your words far and wide, reaching even the most distant corners. If you speak of blowing things up, or of shootings, you can be assured that some will take your words to heart, and the echoes of your voice may reach the ears of those who wield power and authority.

The internet is not a place for the faint of heart; it is a place where truth and error can become entwined, where the actions of a few can cast a shadow over the many. It is a place where the innocent can be mistaken for the guilty, and the guilty can escape unpunished. The line between jest and malice can blur, and one must tread carefully lest they fall into the abyss.

In the face of such uncertainty, the school officials must act, for they are the guardians of the flock. They cannot ignore the cry of alarm, for to do so would be to invite disaster upon their heads. Yet, they must also be wary, for not all warnings are worthy of heed. Some may be the gambols of youthful folly, or the harmless musings of a mind at play.

In the end, it is a delicate balance, this dance between freedom and responsibility. If you do not wish your words to be seen, then do not place them where they may be found. The internet is a public forum, and all who enter must be prepared to bear the consequences of their actions. It is a harsh and unforgiving world, and one must tread carefully lest they find themselves lost in its wilderness.

In the vast, bleak expanse of time, this war has stretched on like a tireless plague, its purpose, once clear as the first light of day, now lost in the mire of its own duration. In the beginning, it was said we fought to bring democracy to a land where none held sway. A noble cause, it seemed, yet now, the motivations seem clouded, tainted by the personal enmities of a past long since passed. Bush Senior's old grievances with Hussein, the echoes of which still linger in the halls of power, cast a shadow over this endeavor. Yet, if the purpose was once to free a people from a tyrant's grip, then it was a cause worthy of our attention. But we have strayed from this path, lost in the labyrinth of our own hubris.

The war's inception was a stark declaration, a bold stroke on the canvas of history. But the subsequent years, they've been a desolate wasteland, a test of endurance rather than a battle for victory. We've become a people content to fight for the sake of fighting, to prove our might, our power. Yet, in this endless cycle of violence, we've lost sight of the cause that birthed us.

The economy, our own, bleeds red from this war. It is a wound that does not heal, a drain that cannot be stopped. Our own citizens suffer, their needs unmet, while abroad, we pour billions into a conflict that has lost its meaning. Poverty, roads, schools, healthcare - these are the battles we should be fighting, the causes we should be championing. Yet, we squander our resources on a war that has become a shadow of its former self, a ghost that haunts the landscape.

It is time, I think, for this war to end. For the people of this land to stand on their own two feet, to face their own demons. We have done what we could, and then some. But now, we must step back, let them face the sun and the wind, and the storms that will inevitably come. For it is their land, their people, their future that should concern them. Not ours.

The time has come to withdraw, to leave the battlefield and tend to our own. The war, it has gone on long enough. It is time to bring our sons and daughters home, to tend to the wounds of a nation that has seen too much bloodshed, and not enough progress. It is time to build, to heal, to grow. For it is in peace that true strength is found, in the quiet moments between the battles.

Can I pose a query for clarification, please?

Seems to me, this matter was circumvented because someone took it upon themselves to surf the web and uncover certain information. I'm not one to contend that this constitutes an invasion of privacy. On platforms such as Myspace, if one chooses to share their life, it's a fair indication that they expect others to see it. Of course, one must ascertain the terms of such exposure. Myspace, for instance, necessitates mutual agreement to view another's profile. You must accept someone as a "friend" for their information to be accessible. When one posts anything online, they implicitly consent to a broad audience.

Yet, the issue is complex. Is it feasible for a single individual to monitor every student's profile in a school to prevent such occurrences? It could be seen as discriminatory if the intent is to scrutinize the "bad" students. However, if the profile was stumbled upon during an actual investigation, it might be justified. I'm uncertain.

In my experience, I have no Myspace of my own but I do possess a Facebook. It troubles me to know that there are individuals who can glean personal information from such a platform. I've seen a television report about a man who easily found a young girl's screen name and convinced her to meet him within minutes. I wouldn't entertain such a request, but some of my acquaintances have encountered strangers knowing their online persona. It's an uncomfortable situation. I limit what I post, but I also understand the need to communicate with friends. The challenge lies in balancing privacy and connection.

My roommate shared a tale of her high school days, where students were prohibited from having Myspace accounts by the school. I found that peculiar. I wasn't sure how school officials could impose such restrictions. It seems a grey area, a privacy issue perhaps, but I'm not convinced they have the authority to dictate such limitations. That's the extent of my thoughts on the matter.

Now, the matter of gender discrimination, it runs deep in this land, like a river carved by time. Not merely against women, but in every sector of labor, it festers. The glass ceiling, that mythical barrier of supposed equality, it is a constant stone in the shoe of ambition.

In the corporate world, a woman may stand tall, possessing every qualification for a position, yet the board may shrink from her, for society has long seen men as the natural leaders. A woman, in this predicament, is like a lioness in a den of hyenas, her power acknowledged but never truly accepted. The same can be said for men in fields like fashion, where the male presence is often met with skepticism. Society whispers, "How can a man know feminine tastes?" as if it is a secret language known only to women.

The change, it is a slow process, like a river carving stone. Women, they are climbing ladders of success, reaching heights once deemed unattainable. Yet, the pace is slow, the climb arduous. Change, it is not a storm that sweeps away the old, but a gentle rain that wears away the stone.

And then there are those who defy societal norms, like the man who chooses to stay at home, to raise his children. Society looks askance, whispering, "What man would choose to stay at home?" as if it is a sign of weakness. Yet, these men, they are not weak, but strong in their choice to nurture, to guide the next generation. They are the silent rebels, the quiet revolutionaries.

In the fashion industry, a man's place is often questioned. "How can he know the female psyche?" they ask, as if it is a foreign language. Yet, these men, they are not mere mimics, but interpreters, translating the world of fashion into a language that transcends gender.

Discrimination, it is not merely about gender, but about every aspect of a person. A man from the farm, with rough hands and grammar like a river's roar, may stand before a room of men, his intelligence unquestioned, but his grammar a stumbling block. "How can we trust him?" they ask, as if a man's worth is measured by the rules of grammar.

Yes, discrimination, it is a serpent that coils around every aspect of society. Change, it is coming, but it is not a storm, but a slow, steady rain. We must be patient, and persistent, for the stone will yield, and the river will carve a new path.

In my apprehension, the matter at hand is not that they have legalized it, no. They have decriminalized it, reduced the sin from a criminal transgression to a trifle, akin to a speeding ticket. It is a mere citation now, no need for the clanking of cuffs or the cold embrace of the jailhouse. A marijuana charge, once a stain on one's record, now holds less weight, though the stigma persists. The specter of a drug charge looms large in the minds of the youth, as it does in any aspirant's. The decriminalization, while lessening the burden on the courts and the coffers, does not erase the stain entirely. Yet, it is a step forward, a recognition of the fact that the price of prosecution is high, and the cost of incarceration, higher still.

Denver, with its peculiar brand of openness, has embraced this change. Their coffers, once emptied by the endless prosecution of the pot heads, are now filled. Schools have been built, elder care funded, and the hungry fed. It is a testament to the power of policy change, to the fact that sometimes, less is more.

But, is it right to have marijuana on every corner, like the stench of smoke from the factory? No, I think not. It is a taboo, a vice, and it should remain so. The effects of marijuana, though not as immediate as alcohol, can be just as insidious. It is a poison, a sedative, a blight on the mind. Yet, it is not a one-size-fits-all vice. Some men, they can handle it, exercise moderation, and walk a narrow path. Others, they cannot. They embrace it, and it consumes them.

It is a complex beast, this decriminalization. It is not the answer to all our ills, nor is it the harbinger of doom. It is a step, a compromises, a recognition that the old ways are not working. It is a conversation, a dialogue, a recognition that we must address the elephant in the room. And in the end, it is a choice, a choice to be made by each of us, as individuals, as communities, as a society. And it is a choice we must make with our eyes wide open, our minds clear, and our hearts heavy with the weight of the consequences.

I'd say yes, in a way. For so long as the flame burns, it is wise to retain the embers of tradition. Though the embers glow with a familiar warmth, they must not be allowed to smother the winds of change. This is the dance of faith, a tango of continuity and adaptation, both necessary for a soul's sustenance.

The Catholic Church, as vast as the desert, has seen its share of the sun and the shadow. Its traditions, like the ancient oak, stand firm and proud. Yet, the roots of the tree must bend with the shifting earth lest they snap in the storm. The weekly pilgrimage to the church, the rigid observance of doctrine, they all echo the echoes of the past. But the past is not a prison, and the Church must never forget its teachings on love, for it is a love that transcends the boundaries of dogma.

My parents, one a Catholic, the other an Episcopalian, could not find solace in the same house of God. The Church, in its rigidity, turned a blind eye to the union of their hearts. This is not the path of the truly devout, who seek to love as they are loved. It is a contradiction, as vast as the cosmos, that the Church preaches love while closing its doors to those who do not fit the mold.

The priests, the guardians of the faith, are not immune to the darkness within. Marriage, they say, would assuage the beast, but I question it. For the beast is not sated by the embrace of a spouse, but by the innocents it preys upon. Allowing priests to wed would not stop the rot within, for the rot is not in the vows of marriage, but in the hearts of men themselves. Allowing them to wed, I believe, would only shift the sands, not extinguish the flame.

Now, listen here, I haven't made any decision on this here matter yet. It's a right tight thing, it is. The church and the state, they're close enough that you can't tug 'em apart without causing a damn ruckus. And marriage, well, that's a tricky thing too. The government wants to define it, but they don't want to offend no one. Civil unions, that's what they call it. But is it really a marriage? It's just two people, joined together. Shouldn't the government leave it at that? And what about the constitution, they want to amend it to ban gay marriage. That's ridiculous, it is. The constitution's not a place for such a small cause, it ain't. It's not important enough to amend, don't you see? No, it isn't.

In the hardscrabble crucible of my upbringing, I was cradled in the tenets of a Christian household. Yet, the labyrinth of my mind is not so easily confined to such rigid beliefs. Homosexuality, to me, is a realm of gray areas, a shadowed expanse where the light of understanding is but a flickering candle. For I am acquainted with many who tread that path, and though I do not walk it myself, I do not deny them the freedom to do so.

The question of its legality, though, is a matter of state's rights. In this vast and varied land, where the winds of democracy and the tides of conservatism ebb and flow, it seems only right that each state should decide for itself whether to legalize this union. For what is a nation but a collection of sovereign parts, each with its own voice and will?

I stand firm in my belief that all should be afforded equality under the law, that no one should be denied the opportunities that others take for granted. It is a matter of justice, plain and simple. The federal government, with its distant and often capricious authority, should not impose its will upon the people. It is up to each state to decide what is best for its citizens, to hear their voices and act accordingly.

To suggest that a single president, no matter how long they may remain in office, can dictate the will of the entire nation is as absurd as claiming the sun rises only in Texas. This is a land of states, each with its own character, its own soul. It is not the business of one man or one party to decide what is right for all. Let the states decide, and let the people live with the consequences.

I am not here to argue, but to speak the truth as I see it. It is a truth that echoes through the silence of the wilderness, a truth that says, "Let each man and woman stand for themselves, and let each state stand for its own people."

Now, let me see here. That ain't to be taken as such a private affair, no sir. Everything you post on the internet, it's there for the world to see. It's like the wind, blowing where it may. And if the school officials should happen to stumble upon it, well, that's just the way it is.

Just like if you're posting about such things as drinking or smoking or what have you, you're asking for it. It's a public thing, and the school has a responsibility to ensure it's a safe place for all. If it's something that's gonna keep the kids safe, then by all means, they should be checking.

But if they're just going to snoop around, that's a different story. That's like sticking your nose where it ain't wanted. But if it's for the safety of the school, then I reckon it's all right.

It's a bit like when you're at the water's edge, and you see something there that might be harmful. You check it out, you see if it's safe. If it's not, you warn the others. That's what they're doing with these here internet things, checking if there's something harmful floating about.

Now, I ain't one to be surprised about how careless folks can be. It's like I once told a teacher of mine, "If you post something online, it's like you're painting it on the side of a building. You can't take it down, not once it's seen." And if a person's gotta go to college, they'd best remember that. They're gonna be judged on what they've done and said before, and it's gonna stay with 'em. That's just the way it is.

I mean, if something's leading to a safer place for the students, then fine, check it out. But if it's just for catching folks in trouble, that's a different matter. That's like hunting a man just for the sport of it. Not right, not at all.

And I say this: If parents drop off their kids at school, they expect a place of safety. And the school officials are just doing their job, making sure that place is safe. It's like the drills we used to do, back in high school. They were for the safety of all. And that's what they're doing here, making sure nothing bad happens. Like that tragic business at Columbine. That could have been prevented with just a bit of looking out.

So that's all I've got to say. That's all I can figure on.

Ah, the war. A wretched affair, it was. At first, I was all for it, you see. The specter of nine-eleven still lingered heavy, and I thought, perhaps, we should repay them in kind. But now, I'm not so sure. I reckon we were blinded by emotion, by the desire for vengeance. We stormed their lands, unprepared, unplanned. A fool's errand, it was.

I do believe the people there, they're caught in a cycle of violence, of chaos. They can't seem to turn it off, can't turn it toward anything else but each other. And we, we're just a distraction. A foreign force, trying to impose order on a land that's already been torn asunder. It's futile, I tell you. Like trying to tame a wild beast, you can only do so much before it turns on you.

We went in there seeking revenge, and we got it. But at what cost? The people there, they're not like us. Their war is not our war. They fight for different reasons, with different rules. And in the end, they'll be just as they were before we arrived. We can't change that.

President Bush, he was a man driven by emotion, by the desire to do something, anything. And the people, they wanted action. But it was a hasty decision, a decision made in the heat of the moment. We didn't have a plan, a strategy. We were like children with a toy, playing at war. And look where it's gotten us.

Now, I don't know. I don't know if we've made any progress. I see the rebuilding, but it's like trying to repair a house with a leaking roof. You can patch it up, but it'll still rain inside. We can't stay there forever, and once we leave, what then? Another cycle of violence, of chaos. It's a vicious circle, and we're just a part of it.

But enough of this. I've said my piece. The war, it's a mistake. A mistake we're all paying for.

transformed_texts: The Catholic Church, in its current form, stands embattled. Its stance on topics such as gay marriage, abortion, and birth control seems to have become anachronistic, alienating those who espouse differing views. The Church's unyielding stances on these issues have not only sparked discord but also dwindled its flock. In this age of shifting societal norms, the Church's perspective appears outdated, a relic of a bygone era. Could a more contemporary outlook on these matters reinvigorate its following? Perhaps, but the path to adaptation is fraught with challenges. The Church's resistance to change, its rigid stance, and its refusal to acknowledge the shifting tides of societal opinion have led many to turn away, seeking more progressive and accepting communities. This exodus is understandable. For those who support abortion rights or advocate for same-sex marriage, following a Church that condemns their beliefs can be akin to spiritual martyrdom. The Church's insistence on celibacy for priests, though steadfast, seems anachronistic in a world where marriage and family are widely accepted as integral parts of life. Would allowing priests to marry or ordain women truly change the Church's trajectory? It is difficult to say, as the Church's current structure has long been established, resistant to change. Yet, in a world that is continually evolving, perhaps the time has come for the Church to reckon with its past and embrace a new path, one that is more inclusive and adaptable to the winds of change.

I'm not one to stand against the union of two souls, be they of differing sexes or the same. It's not a choice, not something one can pick up and put down like a hat. They are who they are, born of flesh and blood, as you and I. It's not a conscious decision, like choosing one's favorite shade of whiskey. They shouldn't be held accountable for their inclinations, for it's as natural as the sun rising. It's not a matter for the federal government to step in on. They should mind their own business, leave the people alone. It's not a moral issue, nor a legal one. It's just life, raw and unfiltered. Let them be, let them love, for it's the only way to be truly free.

I believe gay marriage should be legalized, for there are no compelling reasons against it. Many argue that such unions pose a threat to the traditional family, but this is a misguided notion. It is a matter of perspective, a different side of the same coin, if you will. Heads and tails, yet they are the same in essence. Moreover, civil rights extend to homosexual couples, encompassing property taxes and healthcare, where one’s partner cannot visit or be present during illness if not technically family. This seems silly, given the lifelong commitment shared. Scientific studies, a hot topic as it is, reveal that homosexual couples experience similar relationship success and satisfaction as heterosexual ones.

They do not seek the right to wed in a church but merely a legal marriage certificate from the government. Separation of church and state should be respected, and if one is granted civil unions, why not marriages? It is akin to segregation, separate but unequal. The community may worry about adoption and how children of gay couples will fare, but parenting skills are identical, and children will adapt as they always do.

The federal government should intervene to legalize gay marriage in all states, opposing the amendment. However, President Bush's strong beliefs on the matter, rooted in his religious views, present a challenge. His stance on abortion and stem cell research is similarly rooted in morality, which differs among individuals. The government embracing one group's morality while ignoring others is unethical, hypocritical given the recent controversies surrounding religious standards in the pledge of allegiance.

Many oppose gay marriage due to the belief that homosexuality is a result of psychological damage or trauma. This is unfounded, as the American Psychological Association has debunked such notions. Ignoring scientific research and relying on popular opinion is detrimental. Institutions that conduct studies on these subjects should be trusted over personal beliefs and religious doctrine.

Well, first off, I'm employed at the hospital pharmacy for the summer. Now, I ain't no lawyer or politician, but I can tell you this: just 'cause a drug is illegal don't mean it ain't got any good in it. You see, I'm talking 'bout marijuana.

You know, the world's got a habit of turning its back on something 'cause it's deemed illegal. But the truth is, there's a whole world of benefits hidden behind that stigma. Now, I ain't saying it should be handed out to children or fools, but for medicinal purposes? Hell yeah, I'd say it's worth considering. After all, look at all the controlled substances we use in hospitals every day - oxycodone, vicodin, percocets. They ain't exactly the brightest of the bunch, but they do their job, and that's what matters.

Now, you might be thinking, well, what about the abuse? Well, let me tell you, alcohol's just as harmful when it's abused. But we don't throw the baby out with the bathwater, do we? No, we integrate it gradually, legalize it responsibly. And that's what we need to do with marijuana. First, we gotta chip away at that taboo, get rid of that nasty image they've got painted up there. Make people see it for what it is - not some horrid thing, but a plant with potential.

So yeah, I'd say it's time we took a step back, looked at the facts, and embrace the benefits. Who knows, maybe we'll find a way to make it work for everybody.

In these times, the church has adapted to the twenty-first century, though not in the rigid manner of yore. The dress code, once as strict as the Ten Commandments, has loosened, as have the trappings of worship. Sundays, once filled with the solemnity of youthful piety, have given way to the casualness of modern life. Gone are the days of matching dresses, shoes, and purses; now, the masses are shortened to mere thirty minutes, and the congregation dresses as if they've just stepped from the sand, salt still clinging to their skin. The church, once a place of unyielding formality, is now a sanctuary of relaxed informality.

As for the accusations against the Catholic Church, I cannot say with certainty what could have been done to prevent the darkness that has unfolded. Some may claim that allowing female priests or permitting marriage would have made a difference, but I am not convinced. For the malady of pedophilia, it seems a matter of genetics, not choice or circumstance. The beast within does not yield to the sanctity of marriage or the piety of a calling. Had the church been privy to such darkness and covered it up, shame be upon them. But I do not believe all were aware, and thus, no redemption can be found in hindsight.

Well, this here, it's a tale of deceit and bloodshed, and I reckon it all began with the September 11th attacks. The wind of war blew through the nation, and the Bush administration, they latched onto it, claiming Iraq had weapons of mass destruction and was connected to Bin Laden. Lies, all lies, and the people, they swallowed them whole, eyes wide with fear and grief.

I remember the Bush administration's words like a bad penny, always turning up, always telling tales that didn't add up. Colin Powell, he stood at the UN, his voice like a tolling bell, and now, in hindsight, he says he wasn't convinced. That's malfeasance, that's a stain on the office, an impeachable offense. They lied to us, the American people, and they're still liars today.

The Iraq war, it's like a cancer, eating away at the heart of the United States. The younger Bush, he had a score to settle with Saddam Hussein, a blood vengeance burning in his eyes. And oil, they were after the oil, the black gold, a river of wealth. It's all underhanded, a snake in the grass, and it's gone on too long.

Now, they say we can't withdraw, not yet. Civil war, they say, and more bloodshed. A coalition of nations, Syria and Saudi Arabia, they're coming in, trying to right the ship. But it's a raft of troubles, that's what it is. Iraq's sovereignty, it's like a ghost, haunting the halls of power. The interim government, it's a house of cards, ready to crumble. The Parliament, it's a powder keg, filled with radical elements vying for control.

None of it, none of it, is good for polite company. But it's the truth, and the truth is a harsh mistress, she don't sugarcoat nothing.

I reckon that it ain't right to make it legal or for a state to even declare it as such. The constitution, it speaks clear as day about the separation of church and state. It's a line that's been drawn in the sand, and I reckon tampering with it would be a defiance of what's already been written in stone. Now, there's them out there who'd see it made illegal, but that's just one church's belief over another. The Catholics and Christians, they're against it, save for a few in Boston and such. But I don't think it's the government's place to decide what a church can or can't make illegal. Separation, it's been a key part of this here constitution, and that's what allows for religious tolerance in this land. And even if they were to make an amendment, it'd be a step in the wrong direction. It'd be the only amendment to restrict the people, and that ain't right. No, I don't think the federal government or any government should be involved. It's personal beliefs, nothing more, driving this push for an amendment. It's about one religion over every other, and that ain't fair. I reckon it's up to the churches to decide this, not the president or any government. And there ain't no reason to amend it, except for personal views. It might even have a positive impact on society, I reckon. That's all I got to say.

In the dark, murky waters of Iraq, a nation's fate has been set ablaze by the iron fist of American might. The government, with a tongue as slick as the desert sand, spun a web of deceit, binding the people to the war machine that was to come. The 9/11 specter was invoked, a shadow of terror that twisted the minds of the masses, and the invasion of Iraq, a preemptive strike, was the result of this twisted dance. I, myself, stood against the tide of war, particularly a strike that was more impetuous than strategic.

The echoes of Vietnam resonated in Iraq, a ghostly echo of past mistakes. The removal of a government, the vacuum of power, the chaos that followed - these were not the fruits of a well-planned harvest. The American government, it seemed, had not learned from the past, and the cost was high. The blood of American soldiers stained the sands, and yet the task of building a democracy in a land torn apart by war had barely begun.

The government attempted to mask the uncertainty and chaos that followed the invasion, presenting it as a clear, swift victory. But I saw the truth, a grim shadow that refused to be banished. The task of rebuilding a nation was not one to be rushed, nor was it a simple matter of training an army to replace the old regime. It was a long, arduous journey, much like our own struggle for democracy, and the government's portrayal of it as an easy task was a lie.

In the election of 2004, I weighed the candidates, their promises, their plans. It was a difficult choice, for the war had become a part of our reality, a grim specter that followed us. The question remained: how could we abandon those we had liberated? The cost was high, the risk great, and the goal was unclear. The oil, the resources, the need to control - these were the true reasons behind the invasion, not the weapons of mass destruction that were never found.

As the war drags on, I hope for peace, but I know it will not come easily. The path to a free, democratic Iraq is long and fraught with peril, and the government's promises of a swift victory were nothing more than the same old lies. The war in Iraq, like a cancer, continues to fester, a grim reminder of the cost of war and the deceit of those who would lead us into it.

Well, I reckon I should set my thoughts on this matter straight. I've always been of the mind that a person's inclination towards any manner of love or affection is a personal and intimate affair, not something to be dictated by the whims of law or the pious pronouncements of the powerful. It's been proven, or so I've heard from learned folk, that this predisposition has more to do with our biology than our upbringing. It ain't something that can be controlled or changed, much like the color of one's eyes or the curve of one's smile.

In my own neighborhood, I've seen it firsthand. There are those who choose to love in a way that don't fit the mold of traditional expectations. They walk their dogs, they tend their gardens, they live their lives just like anyone else. But they're denied the same rights as their neighbors simply because their love don't follow the societal script.

And all this talk about marriage being a sacred institution, well, that's a mighty convenient thing for them to say, don't you think? As if it's not something that can be done in private, without the prying eyes of the government or the sanctimonious gaze of the pious. If a man and a woman want to tie the knot, they can do it in a heartbeat, with barely a whisper. But if two men or two women want to do the same, it's a spectacle, a headline.

It's my belief, and I've heard it said by others too, that this inclination is something written into our very being, something that can't be changed or shamed away. It's as natural as the sun rising or the moon setting. And it's high time we started treating it as such. It's not a political issue, it's a matter of basic humanity.

When you venture forth into the digital realm, you tread on a path where all is laid bare for the world to see. The internet, it seems, is a vast and unforgiving wilderness, where the shadows of our words and deeds can be cast upon the minds of others. As a Resident Assistant, I've witnessed firsthand the consequences of such careless exploration. You see, when you place something on the internet, it becomes a part of the collective consciousness, a public forum for all to peruse and scrutinize.

In the realm of the digital frontier, there is no sanctuary. The wind of rumor can carry your words far and wide, reaching even the most distant corners. If you speak of blowing things up, or of shootings, you can be assured that some will take your words to heart, and the echoes of your voice may reach the ears of those who wield power and authority.

The internet is not a place for the faint of heart; it is a place where truth and error can become entwined, where the actions of a few can cast a shadow over the many. It is a place where the innocent can be mistaken for the guilty, and the guilty can escape unpunished. The line between jest and malice can blur, and one must tread carefully lest they fall into the abyss.

In the face of such uncertainty, the school officials must act, for they are the guardians of the flock. They cannot ignore the cry of alarm, for to do so would be to invite disaster upon their heads. Yet, they must also be wary, for not all warnings are worthy of heed. Some may be the gambols of youthful folly, or the harmless musings of a mind at play.

In the end, it is a delicate balance, this dance between freedom and responsibility. If you do not wish your words to be seen, then do not place them where they may be found. The internet is a public forum, and all who enter must be prepared to bear the consequences of their actions. It is a harsh and unforgiving world, and one must tread carefully lest they find themselves lost in its wilderness.

In the vast, bleak expanse of time, this war has stretched on like a tireless plague, its purpose, once clear as the first light of day, now lost in the mire of its own duration. In the beginning, it was said we fought to bring democracy to a land where none held sway. A noble cause, it seemed, yet now, the motivations seem clouded, tainted by the personal enmities of a past long since passed. Bush Senior's old grievances with Hussein, the echoes of which still linger in the halls of power, cast a shadow over this endeavor. Yet, if the purpose was once to free a people from a tyrant's grip, then it was a cause worthy of our attention. But we have strayed from this path, lost in the labyrinth of our own hubris.

The war's inception was a stark declaration, a bold stroke on the canvas of history. But the subsequent years, they've been a desolate wasteland, a test of endurance rather than a battle for victory. We've become a people content to fight for the sake of fighting, to prove our might, our power. Yet, in this endless cycle of violence, we've lost sight of the cause that birthed us.

The economy, our own, bleeds red from this war. It is a wound that does not heal, a drain that cannot be stopped. Our own citizens suffer, their needs unmet, while abroad, we pour billions into a conflict that has lost its meaning. Poverty, roads, schools, healthcare - these are the battles we should be fighting, the causes we should be championing. Yet, we squander our resources on a war that has become a shadow of its former self, a ghost that haunts the landscape.

It is time, I think, for this war to end. For the people of this land to stand on their own two feet, to face their own demons. We have done what we could, and then some. But now, we must step back, let them face the sun and the wind, and the storms that will inevitably come. For it is their land, their people, their future that should concern them. Not ours.

The time has come to withdraw, to leave the battlefield and tend to our own. The war, it has gone on long enough. It is time to bring our sons and daughters home, to tend to the wounds of a nation that has seen too much bloodshed, and not enough progress. It is time to build, to heal, to grow. For it is in peace that true strength is found, in the quiet moments between the battles.

Can I pose a query for clarification, please?

Seems to me, this matter was circumvented because someone took it upon themselves to surf the web and uncover certain information. I'm not one to contend that this constitutes an invasion of privacy. On platforms such as Myspace, if one chooses to share their life, it's a fair indication that they expect others to see it. Of course, one must ascertain the terms of such exposure. Myspace, for instance, necessitates mutual agreement to view another's profile. You must accept someone as a "friend" for their information to be accessible. When one posts anything online, they implicitly consent to a broad audience.

Yet, the issue is complex. Is it feasible for a single individual to monitor every student's profile in a school to prevent such occurrences? It could be seen as discriminatory if the intent is to scrutinize the "bad" students. However, if the profile was stumbled upon during an actual investigation, it might be justified. I'm uncertain.

In my experience, I have no Myspace of my own but I do possess a Facebook. It troubles me to know that there are individuals who can glean personal information from such a platform. I've seen a television report about a man who easily found a young girl's screen name and convinced her to meet him within minutes. I wouldn't entertain such a request, but some of my acquaintances have encountered strangers knowing their online persona. It's an uncomfortable situation. I limit what I post, but I also understand the need to communicate with friends. The challenge lies in balancing privacy and connection.

My roommate shared a tale of her high school days, where students were prohibited from having Myspace accounts by the school. I found that peculiar. I wasn't sure how school officials could impose such restrictions. It seems a grey area, a privacy issue perhaps, but I'm not convinced they have the authority to dictate such limitations. That's the extent of my thoughts on the matter.

Now, the matter of gender discrimination, it runs deep in this land, like a river carved by time. Not merely against women, but in every sector of labor, it festers. The glass ceiling, that mythical barrier of supposed equality, it is a constant stone in the shoe of ambition.

In the corporate world, a woman may stand tall, possessing every qualification for a position, yet the board may shrink from her, for society has long seen men as the natural leaders. A woman, in this predicament, is like a lioness in a den of hyenas, her power acknowledged but never truly accepted. The same can be said for men in fields like fashion, where the male presence is often met with skepticism. Society whispers, "How can a man know feminine tastes?" as if it is a secret language known only to women.

The change, it is a slow process, like a river carving stone. Women, they are climbing ladders of success, reaching heights once deemed unattainable. Yet, the pace is slow, the climb arduous. Change, it is not a storm that sweeps away the old, but a gentle rain that wears away the stone.

And then there are those who defy societal norms, like the man who chooses to stay at home, to raise his children. Society looks askance, whispering, "What man would choose to stay at home?" as if it is a sign of weakness. Yet, these men, they are not weak, but strong in their choice to nurture, to guide the next generation. They are the silent rebels, the quiet revolutionaries.

In the fashion industry, a man's place is often questioned. "How can he know the female psyche?" they ask, as if it is a foreign language. Yet, these men, they are not mere mimics, but interpreters, translating the world of fashion into a language that transcends gender.

Discrimination, it is not merely about gender, but about every aspect of a person. A man from the farm, with rough hands and grammar like a river's roar, may stand before a room of men, his intelligence unquestioned, but his grammar a stumbling block. "How can we trust him?" they ask, as if a man's worth is measured by the rules of grammar.

Yes, discrimination, it is a serpent that coils around every aspect of society. Change, it is coming, but it is not a storm, but a slow, steady rain. We must be patient, and persistent, for the stone will yield, and the river will carve a new path.

In my apprehension, the matter at hand is not that they have legalized it, no. They have decriminalized it, reduced the sin from a criminal transgression to a trifle, akin to a speeding ticket. It is a mere citation now, no need for the clanking of cuffs or the cold embrace of the jailhouse. A marijuana charge, once a stain on one's record, now holds less weight, though the stigma persists. The specter of a drug charge looms large in the minds of the youth, as it does in any aspirant's. The decriminalization, while lessening the burden on the courts and the coffers, does not erase the stain entirely. Yet, it is a step forward, a recognition of the fact that the price of prosecution is high, and the cost of incarceration, higher still.

Denver, with its peculiar brand of openness, has embraced this change. Their coffers, once emptied by the endless prosecution of the pot heads, are now filled. Schools have been built, elder care funded, and the hungry fed. It is a testament to the power of policy change, to the fact that sometimes, less is more.

But, is it right to have marijuana on every corner, like the stench of smoke from the factory? No, I think not. It is a taboo, a vice, and it should remain so. The effects of marijuana, though not as immediate as alcohol, can be just as insidious. It is a poison, a sedative, a blight on the mind. Yet, it is not a one-size-fits-all vice. Some men, they can handle it, exercise moderation, and walk a narrow path. Others, they cannot. They embrace it, and it consumes them.

It is a complex beast, this decriminalization. It is not the answer to all our ills, nor is it the harbinger of doom. It is a step, a compromises, a recognition that the old ways are not working. It is a conversation, a dialogue, a recognition that we must address the elephant in the room. And in the end, it is a choice, a choice to be made by each of us, as individuals, as communities, as a society. And it is a choice we must make with our eyes wide open, our minds clear, and our hearts heavy with the weight of the consequences.

I'd say yes, in a way. For so long as the flame burns, it is wise to retain the embers of tradition. Though the embers glow with a familiar warmth, they must not be allowed to smother the winds of change. This is the dance of faith, a tango of continuity and adaptation, both necessary for a soul's sustenance.

The Catholic Church, as vast as the desert, has seen its share of the sun and the shadow. Its traditions, like the ancient oak, stand firm and proud. Yet, the roots of the tree must bend with the shifting earth lest they snap in the storm. The weekly pilgrimage to the church, the rigid observance of doctrine, they all echo the echoes of the past. But the past is not a prison, and the Church must never forget its teachings on love, for it is a love that transcends the boundaries of dogma.

My parents, one a Catholic, the other an Episcopalian, could not find solace in the same house of God. The Church, in its rigidity, turned a blind eye to the union of their hearts. This is not the path of the truly devout, who seek to love as they are loved. It is a contradiction, as vast as the cosmos, that the Church preaches love while closing its doors to those who do not fit the mold.

The priests, the guardians of the faith, are not immune to the darkness within. Marriage, they say, would assuage the beast, but I question it. For the beast is not sated by the embrace of a spouse, but by the innocents it preys upon. Allowing priests to wed would not stop the rot within, for the rot is not in the vows of marriage, but in the hearts of men themselves. Allowing them to wed, I believe, would only shift the sands, not extinguish the flame.

Now, listen here, I haven't made any decision on this here matter yet. It's a right tight thing, it is. The church and the state, they're close enough that you can't tug 'em apart without causing a damn ruckus. And marriage, well, that's a tricky thing too. The government wants to define it, but they don't want to offend no one. Civil unions, that's what they call it. But is it really a marriage? It's just two people, joined together. Shouldn't the government leave it at that? And what about the constitution, they want to amend it to ban gay marriage. That's ridiculous, it is. The constitution's not a place for such a small cause, it ain't. It's not important enough to amend, don't you see? No, it isn't.

In the hardscrabble crucible of my upbringing, I was cradled in the tenets of a Christian household. Yet, the labyrinth of my mind is not so easily confined to such rigid beliefs. Homosexuality, to me, is a realm of gray areas, a shadowed expanse where the light of understanding is but a flickering candle. For I am acquainted with many who tread that path, and though I do not walk it myself, I do not deny them the freedom to do so.

The question of its legality, though, is a matter of state's rights. In this vast and varied land, where the winds of democracy and the tides of conservatism ebb and flow, it seems only right that each state should decide for itself whether to legalize this union. For what is a nation but a collection of sovereign parts, each with its own voice and will?

I stand firm in my belief that all should be afforded equality under the law, that no one should be denied the opportunities that others take for granted. It is a matter of justice, plain and simple. The federal government, with its distant and often capricious authority, should not impose its will upon the people. It is up to each state to decide what is best for its citizens, to hear their voices and act accordingly.

To suggest that a single president, no matter how long they may remain in office, can dictate the will of the entire nation is as absurd as claiming the sun rises only in Texas. This is a land of states, each with its own character, its own soul. It is not the business of one man or one party to decide what is right for all. Let the states decide, and let the people live with the consequences.

I am not here to argue, but to speak the truth as I see it. It is a truth that echoes through the silence of the wilderness, a truth that says, "Let each man and woman stand for themselves, and let each state stand for its own people."

Now, let me see here. That ain't to be taken as such a private affair, no sir. Everything you post on the internet, it's there for the world to see. It's like the wind, blowing where it may. And if the school officials should happen to stumble upon it, well, that's just the way it is.

Just like if you're posting about such things as drinking or smoking or what have you, you're asking for it. It's a public thing, and the school has a responsibility to ensure it's a safe place for all. If it's something that's gonna keep the kids safe, then by all means, they should be checking.

But if they're just going to snoop around, that's a different story. That's like sticking your nose where it ain't wanted. But if it's for the safety of the school, then I reckon it's all right.

It's a bit like when you're at the water's edge, and you see something there that might be harmful. You check it out, you see if it's safe. If it's not, you warn the others. That's what they're doing with these here internet things, checking if there's something harmful floating about.

Now, I ain't one to be surprised about how careless folks can be. It's like I once told a teacher of mine, "If you post something online, it's like you're painting it on the side of a building. You can't take it down, not once it's seen." And if a person's gotta go to college, they'd best remember that. They're gonna be judged on what they've done and said before, and it's gonna stay with 'em. That's just the way it is.

I mean, if something's leading to a safer place for the students, then fine, check it out. But if it's just for catching folks in trouble, that's a different matter. That's like hunting a man just for the sport of it. Not right, not at all.

And I say this: If parents drop off their kids at school, they expect a place of safety. And the school officials are just doing their job, making sure that place is safe. It's like the drills we used to do, back in high school. They were for the safety of all. And that's what they're doing here, making sure nothing bad happens. Like that tragic business at Columbine. That could have been prevented with just a bit of looking out.

So that's all I've got to say. That's all I can figure on.

Ah, the war. A wretched affair, it was. At first, I was all for it, you see. The specter of nine-eleven still lingered heavy, and I thought, perhaps, we should repay them in kind. But now, I'm not so sure. I reckon we were blinded by emotion, by the desire for vengeance. We stormed their lands, unprepared, unplanned. A fool's errand, it was.

I do believe the people there, they're caught in a cycle of violence, of chaos. They can't seem to turn it off, can't turn it toward anything else but each other. And we, we're just a distraction. A foreign force, trying to impose order on a land that's already been torn asunder. It's futile, I tell you. Like trying to tame a wild beast, you can only do so much before it turns on you.

We went in there seeking revenge, and we got it. But at what cost? The people there, they're not like us. Their war is not our war. They fight for different reasons, with different rules. And in the end, they'll be just as they were before we arrived. We can't change that.

President Bush, he was a man driven by emotion, by the desire to do something, anything. And the people, they wanted action. But it was a hasty decision, a decision made in the heat of the moment. We didn't have a plan, a strategy. We were like children with a toy, playing at war. And look where it's gotten us.

Now, I don't know. I don't know if we've made any progress. I see the rebuilding, but it's like trying to repair a house with a leaking roof. You can patch it up, but it'll still rain inside. We can't stay there forever, and once we leave, what then? Another cycle of violence, of chaos. It's a vicious circle, and we're just a part of it.

But enough of this. I've said my piece. The war, it's a mistake. A mistake we're all paying for.

transformed_texts: The Catholic Church, in its current form, stands embattled. Its stance on topics such as gay marriage, abortion, and birth control seems to have become anachronistic, alienating those who espouse differing views. The Church's unyielding stances on these issues have not only sparked discord but also dwindled its flock. In this age of shifting societal norms, the Church's perspective appears outdated, a relic of a bygone era. Could a more contemporary outlook on these matters reinvigorate its following? Perhaps, but the path to adaptation is fraught with challenges. The Church's resistance to change, its rigid stance, and its refusal to acknowledge the shifting tides of societal opinion have led many to turn away, seeking more progressive and accepting communities. This exodus is understandable. For those who support abortion rights or advocate for same-sex marriage, following a Church that condemns their beliefs can be akin to spiritual martyrdom. The Church's insistence on celibacy for priests, though steadfast, seems anachronistic in a world where marriage and family are widely accepted as integral parts of life. Would allowing priests to marry or ordain women truly change the Church's trajectory? It is difficult to say, as the Church's current structure has long been established, resistant to change. Yet, in a world that is continually evolving, perhaps the time has come for the Church to reckon with its past and embrace a new path, one that is more inclusive and adaptable to the winds of change.

I'm not one to stand against the union of two souls, be they of differing sexes or the same. It's not a choice, not something one can pick up and put down like a hat. They are who they are, born of flesh and blood, as you and I. It's not a conscious decision, like choosing one's favorite shade of whiskey. They shouldn't be held accountable for their inclinations, for it's as natural as the sun rising. It's not a matter for the federal government to step in on. They should mind their own business, leave the people alone. It's not a moral issue, nor a legal one. It's just life, raw and unfiltered. Let them be, let them love, for it's the only way to be truly free.

I believe gay marriage should be legalized, for there are no compelling reasons against it. Many argue that such unions pose a threat to the traditional family, but this is a misguided notion. It is a matter of perspective, a different side of the same coin, if you will. Heads and tails, yet they are the same in essence. Moreover, civil rights extend to homosexual couples, encompassing property taxes and healthcare, where one’s partner cannot visit or be present during illness if not technically family. This seems silly, given the lifelong commitment shared. Scientific studies, a hot topic as it is, reveal that homosexual couples experience similar relationship success and satisfaction as heterosexual ones.

They do not seek the right to wed in a church but merely a legal marriage certificate from the government. Separation of church and state should be respected, and if one is granted civil unions, why not marriages? It is akin to segregation, separate but unequal. The community may worry about adoption and how children of gay couples will fare, but parenting skills are identical, and children will adapt as they always do.

The federal government should intervene to legalize gay marriage in all states, opposing the amendment. However, President Bush's strong beliefs on the matter, rooted in his religious views, present a challenge. His stance on abortion and stem cell research is similarly rooted in morality, which differs among individuals. The government embracing one group's morality while ignoring others is unethical, hypocritical given the recent controversies surrounding religious standards in the pledge of allegiance.

Many oppose gay marriage due to the belief that homosexuality is a result of psychological damage or trauma. This is unfounded, as the American Psychological Association has debunked such notions. Ignoring scientific research and relying on popular opinion is detrimental. Institutions that conduct studies on these subjects should be trusted over personal beliefs and religious doctrine.

Well, first off, I'm employed at the hospital pharmacy for the summer. Now, I ain't no lawyer or politician, but I can tell you this: just 'cause a drug is illegal don't mean it ain't got any good in it. You see, I'm talking 'bout marijuana.

You know, the world's got a habit of turning its back on something 'cause it's deemed illegal. But the truth is, there's a whole world of benefits hidden behind that stigma. Now, I ain't saying it should be handed out to children or fools, but for medicinal purposes? Hell yeah, I'd say it's worth considering. After all, look at all the controlled substances we use in hospitals every day - oxycodone, vicodin, percocets. They ain't exactly the brightest of the bunch, but they do their job, and that's what matters.

Now, you might be thinking, well, what about the abuse? Well, let me tell you, alcohol's just as harmful when it's abused. But we don't throw the baby out with the bathwater, do we? No, we integrate it gradually, legalize it responsibly. And that's what we need to do with marijuana. First, we gotta chip away at that taboo, get rid of that nasty image they've got painted up there. Make people see it for what it is - not some horrid thing, but a plant with potential.

So yeah, I'd say it's time we took a step back, looked at the facts, and embrace the benefits. Who knows, maybe we'll find a way to make it work for everybody.

In these times, the church has adapted to the twenty-first century, though not in the rigid manner of yore. The dress code, once as strict as the Ten Commandments, has loosened, as have the trappings of worship. Sundays, once filled with the solemnity of youthful piety, have given way to the casualness of modern life. Gone are the days of matching dresses, shoes, and purses; now, the masses are shortened to mere thirty minutes, and the congregation dresses as if they've just stepped from the sand, salt still clinging to their skin. The church, once a place of unyielding formality, is now a sanctuary of relaxed informality.

As for the accusations against the Catholic Church, I cannot say with certainty what could have been done to prevent the darkness that has unfolded. Some may claim that allowing female priests or permitting marriage would have made a difference, but I am not convinced. For the malady of pedophilia, it seems a matter of genetics, not choice or circumstance. The beast within does not yield to the sanctity of marriage or the piety of a calling. Had the church been privy to such darkness and covered it up, shame be upon them. But I do not believe all were aware, and thus, no redemption can be found in hindsight.

Well, this here, it's a tale of deceit and bloodshed, and I reckon it all began with the September 11th attacks. The wind of war blew through the nation, and the Bush administration, they latched onto it, claiming Iraq had weapons of mass destruction and was connected to Bin Laden. Lies, all lies, and the people, they swallowed them whole, eyes wide with fear and grief.

I remember the Bush administration's words like a bad penny, always turning up, always telling tales that didn't add up. Colin Powell, he stood at the UN, his voice like a tolling bell, and now, in hindsight, he says he wasn't convinced. That's malfeasance, that's a stain on the office, an impeachable offense. They lied to us, the American people, and they're still liars today.

The Iraq war, it's like a cancer, eating away at the heart of the United States. The younger Bush, he had a score to settle with Saddam Hussein, a blood vengeance burning in his eyes. And oil, they were after the oil, the black gold, a river of wealth. It's all underhanded, a snake in the grass, and it's gone on too long.

Now, they say we can't withdraw, not yet. Civil war, they say, and more bloodshed. A coalition of nations, Syria and Saudi Arabia, they're coming in, trying to right the ship. But it's a raft of troubles, that's what it is. Iraq's sovereignty, it's like a ghost, haunting the halls of power. The interim government, it's a house of cards, ready to crumble. The Parliament, it's a powder keg, filled with radical elements vying for control.

None of it, none of it, is good for polite company. But it's the truth, and the truth is a harsh mistress, she don't sugarcoat nothing.

I reckon that it ain't right to make it legal or for a state to even declare it as such. The constitution, it speaks clear as day about the separation of church and state. It's a line that's been drawn in the sand, and I reckon tampering with it would be a defiance of what's already been written in stone. Now, there's them out there who'd see it made illegal, but that's just one church's belief over another. The Catholics and Christians, they're against it, save for a few in Boston and such. But I don't think it's the government's place to decide what a church can or can't make illegal. Separation, it's been a key part of this here constitution, and that's what allows for religious tolerance in this land. And even if they were to make an amendment, it'd be a step in the wrong direction. It'd be the only amendment to restrict the people, and that ain't right. No, I don't think the federal government or any government should be involved. It's personal beliefs, nothing more, driving this push for an amendment. It's about one religion over every other, and that ain't fair. I reckon it's up to the churches to decide this, not the president or any government. And there ain't no reason to amend it, except for personal views. It might even have a positive impact on society, I reckon. That's all I got to say.

In the dark, murky waters of Iraq, a nation's fate has been set ablaze by the iron fist of American might. The government, with a tongue as slick as the desert sand, spun a web of deceit, binding the people to the war machine that was to come. The 9/11 specter was invoked, a shadow of terror that twisted the minds of the masses, and the invasion of Iraq, a preemptive strike, was the result of this twisted dance. I, myself, stood against the tide of war, particularly a strike that was more impetuous than strategic.

The echoes of Vietnam resonated in Iraq, a ghostly echo of past mistakes. The removal of a government, the vacuum of power, the chaos that followed - these were not the fruits of a well-planned harvest. The American government, it seemed, had not learned from the past, and the cost was high. The blood of American soldiers stained the sands, and yet the task of building a democracy in a land torn apart by war had barely begun.

The government attempted to mask the uncertainty and chaos that followed the invasion, presenting it as a clear, swift victory. But I saw the truth, a grim shadow that refused to be banished. The task of rebuilding a nation was not one to be rushed, nor was it a simple matter of training an army to replace the old regime. It was a long, arduous journey, much like our own struggle for democracy, and the government's portrayal of it as an easy task was a lie.

In the election of 2004, I weighed the candidates, their promises, their plans. It was a difficult choice, for the war had become a part of our reality, a grim specter that followed us. The question remained: how could we abandon those we had liberated? The cost was high, the risk great, and the goal was unclear. The oil, the resources, the need to control - these were the true reasons behind the invasion, not the weapons of mass destruction that were never found.

As the war drags on, I hope for peace, but I know it will not come easily. The path to a free, democratic Iraq is long and fraught with peril, and the government's promises of a swift victory were nothing more than the same old lies. The war in Iraq, like a cancer, continues to fester, a grim reminder of the cost of war and the deceit of those who would lead us into it.

Well, I reckon I should set my thoughts on this matter straight. I've always been of the mind that a person's inclination towards any manner of love or affection is a personal and intimate affair, not something to be dictated by the whims of law or the pious pronouncements of the powerful. It's been proven, or so I've heard from learned folk, that this predisposition has more to do with our biology than our upbringing. It ain't something that can be controlled or changed, much like the color of one's eyes or the curve of one's smile.

In my own neighborhood, I've seen it firsthand. There are those who choose to love in a way that don't fit the mold of traditional expectations. They walk their dogs, they tend their gardens, they live their lives just like anyone else. But they're denied the same rights as their neighbors simply because their love don't follow the societal script.

And all this talk about marriage being a sacred institution, well, that's a mighty convenient thing for them to say, don't you think? As if it's not something that can be done in private, without the prying eyes of the government or the sanctimonious gaze of the pious. If a man and a woman want to tie the knot, they can do it in a heartbeat, with barely a whisper. But if two men or two women want to do the same, it's a spectacle, a headline.

It's my belief, and I've heard it said by others too, that this inclination is something written into our very being, something that can't be changed or shamed away. It's as natural as the sun rising or the moon setting. And it's high time we started treating it as such. It's not a political issue, it's a matter of basic humanity.

When you venture forth into the digital realm, you tread on a path where all is laid bare for the world to see. The internet, it seems, is a vast and unforgiving wilderness, where the shadows of our words and deeds can be cast upon the minds of others. As a Resident Assistant, I've witnessed firsthand the consequences of such careless exploration. You see, when you place something on the internet, it becomes a part of the collective consciousness, a public forum for all to peruse and scrutinize.

In the realm of the digital frontier, there is no sanctuary. The wind of rumor can carry your words far and wide, reaching even the most distant corners. If you speak of blowing things up, or of shootings, you can be assured that some will take your words to heart, and the echoes of your voice may reach the ears of those who wield power and authority.

The internet is not a place for the faint of heart; it is a place where truth and error can become entwined, where the actions of a few can cast a shadow over the many. It is a place where the innocent can be mistaken for the guilty, and the guilty can escape unpunished. The line between jest and malice can blur, and one must tread carefully lest they fall into the abyss.

In the face of such uncertainty, the school officials must act, for they are the guardians of the flock. They cannot ignore the cry of alarm, for to do so would be to invite disaster upon their heads. Yet, they must also be wary, for not all warnings are worthy of heed. Some may be the gambols of youthful folly, or the harmless musings of a mind at play.

In the end, it is a delicate balance, this dance between freedom and responsibility. If you do not wish your words to be seen, then do not place them where they may be found. The internet is a public forum, and all who enter must be prepared to bear the consequences of their actions. It is a harsh and unforgiving world, and one must tread carefully lest they find themselves lost in its wilderness.

In the vast, bleak expanse of time, this war has stretched on like a tireless plague, its purpose, once clear as the first light of day, now lost in the mire of its own duration. In the beginning, it was said we fought to bring democracy to a land where none held sway. A noble cause, it seemed, yet now, the motivations seem clouded, tainted by the personal enmities of a past long since passed. Bush Senior's old grievances with Hussein, the echoes of which still linger in the halls of power, cast a shadow over this endeavor. Yet, if the purpose was once to free a people from a tyrant's grip, then it was a cause worthy of our attention. But we have strayed from this path, lost in the labyrinth of our own hubris.

The war's inception was a stark declaration, a bold stroke on the canvas of history. But the subsequent years, they've been a desolate wasteland, a test of endurance rather than a battle for victory. We've become a people content to fight for the sake of fighting, to prove our might, our power. Yet, in this endless cycle of violence, we've lost sight of the cause that birthed us.

The economy, our own, bleeds red from this war. It is a wound that does not heal, a drain that cannot be stopped. Our own citizens suffer, their needs unmet, while abroad, we pour billions into a conflict that has lost its meaning. Poverty, roads, schools, healthcare - these are the battles we should be fighting, the causes we should be championing. Yet, we squander our resources on a war that has become a shadow of its former self, a ghost that haunts the landscape.

It is time, I think, for this war to end. For the people of this land to stand on their own two feet, to face their own demons. We have done what we could, and then some. But now, we must step back, let them face the sun and the wind, and the storms that will inevitably come. For it is their land, their people, their future that should concern them. Not ours.

The time has come to withdraw, to leave the battlefield and tend to our own. The war, it has gone on long enough. It is time to bring our sons and daughters home, to tend to the wounds of a nation that has seen too much bloodshed, and not enough progress. It is time to build, to heal, to grow. For it is in peace that true strength is found, in the quiet moments between the battles.

Can I pose a query for clarification, please?

Seems to me, this matter was circumvented because someone took it upon themselves to surf the web and uncover certain information. I'm not one to contend that this constitutes an invasion of privacy. On platforms such as Myspace, if one chooses to share their life, it's a fair indication that they expect others to see it. Of course, one must ascertain the terms of such exposure. Myspace, for instance, necessitates mutual agreement to view another's profile. You must accept someone as a "friend" for their information to be accessible. When one posts anything online, they implicitly consent to a broad audience.

Yet, the issue is complex. Is it feasible for a single individual to monitor every student's profile in a school to prevent such occurrences? It could be seen as discriminatory if the intent is to scrutinize the "bad" students. However, if the profile was stumbled upon during an actual investigation, it might be justified. I'm uncertain.

In my experience, I have no Myspace of my own but I do possess a Facebook. It troubles me to know that there are individuals who can glean personal information from such a platform. I've seen a television report about a man who easily found a young girl's screen name and convinced her to meet him within minutes. I wouldn't entertain such a request, but some of my acquaintances have encountered strangers knowing their online persona. It's an uncomfortable situation. I limit what I post, but I also understand the need to communicate with friends. The challenge lies in balancing privacy and connection.

My roommate shared a tale of her high school days, where students were prohibited from having Myspace accounts by the school. I found that peculiar. I wasn't sure how school officials could impose such restrictions. It seems a grey area, a privacy issue perhaps, but I'm not convinced they have the authority to dictate such limitations. That's the extent of my thoughts on the matter.
