Now, the matter of gender discrimination, it runs deep in this land, like a river carved by time. Not merely against women, but in every sector of labor, it festers. The glass ceiling, that mythical barrier of supposed equality, it is a constant stone in the shoe of ambition.

In the corporate world, a woman may stand tall, possessing every qualification for a position, yet the board may shrink from her, for society has long seen men as the natural leaders. A woman, in this predicament, is like a lioness in a den of hyenas, her power acknowledged but never truly accepted. The same can be said for men in fields like fashion, where the male presence is often met with skepticism. Society whispers, "How can a man know feminine tastes?" as if it is a secret language known only to women.

The change, it is a slow process, like a river carving stone. Women, they are climbing ladders of success, reaching heights once deemed unattainable. Yet, the pace is slow, the climb arduous. Change, it is not a storm that sweeps away the old, but a gentle rain that wears away the stone.

And then there are those who defy societal norms, like the man who chooses to stay at home, to raise his children. Society looks askance, whispering, "What man would choose to stay at home?" as if it is a sign of weakness. Yet, these men, they are not weak, but strong in their choice to nurture, to guide the next generation. They are the silent rebels, the quiet revolutionaries.

In the fashion industry, a man's place is often questioned. "How can he know the female psyche?" they ask, as if it is a foreign language. Yet, these men, they are not mere mimics, but interpreters, translating the world of fashion into a language that transcends gender.

Discrimination, it is not merely about gender, but about every aspect of a person. A man from the farm, with rough hands and grammar like a river's roar, may stand before a room of men, his intelligence unquestioned, but his grammar a stumbling block. "How can we trust him?" they ask, as if a man's worth is measured by the rules of grammar.

Yes, discrimination, it is a serpent that coils around every aspect of society. Change, it is coming, but it is not a storm, but a slow, steady rain. We must be patient, and persistent, for the stone will yield, and the river will carve a new path.

In my apprehension, the matter at hand is not that they have legalized it, no. They have decriminalized it, reduced the sin from a criminal transgression to a trifle, akin to a speeding ticket. It is a mere citation now, no need for the clanking of cuffs or the cold embrace of the jailhouse. A marijuana charge, once a stain on one's record, now holds less weight, though the stigma persists. The specter of a drug charge looms large in the minds of the youth, as it does in any aspirant's. The decriminalization, while lessening the burden on the courts and the coffers, does not erase the stain entirely. Yet, it is a step forward, a recognition of the fact that the price of prosecution is high, and the cost of incarceration, higher still.

Denver, with its peculiar brand of openness, has embraced this change. Their coffers, once emptied by the endless prosecution of the pot heads, are now filled. Schools have been built, elder care funded, and the hungry fed. It is a testament to the power of policy change, to the fact that sometimes, less is more.

But, is it right to have marijuana on every corner, like the stench of smoke from the factory? No, I think not. It is a taboo, a vice, and it should remain so. The effects of marijuana, though not as immediate as alcohol, can be just as insidious. It is a poison, a sedative, a blight on the mind. Yet, it is not a one-size-fits-all vice. Some men, they can handle it, exercise moderation, and walk a narrow path. Others, they cannot. They embrace it, and it consumes them.

It is a complex beast, this decriminalization. It is not the answer to all our ills, nor is it the harbinger of doom. It is a step, a compromises, a recognition that the old ways are not working. It is a conversation, a dialogue, a recognition that we must address the elephant in the room. And in the end, it is a choice, a choice to be made by each of us, as individuals, as communities, as a society. And it is a choice we must make with our eyes wide open, our minds clear, and our hearts heavy with the weight of the consequences.

I'd say yes, in a way. For so long as the flame burns, it is wise to retain the embers of tradition. Though the embers glow with a familiar warmth, they must not be allowed to smother the winds of change. This is the dance of faith, a tango of continuity and adaptation, both necessary for a soul's sustenance.

The Catholic Church, as vast as the desert, has seen its share of the sun and the shadow. Its traditions, like the ancient oak, stand firm and proud. Yet, the roots of the tree must bend with the shifting earth lest they snap in the storm. The weekly pilgrimage to the church, the rigid observance of doctrine, they all echo the echoes of the past. But the past is not a prison, and the Church must never forget its teachings on love, for it is a love that transcends the boundaries of dogma.

My parents, one a Catholic, the other an Episcopalian, could not find solace in the same house of God. The Church, in its rigidity, turned a blind eye to the union of their hearts. This is not the path of the truly devout, who seek to love as they are loved. It is a contradiction, as vast as the cosmos, that the Church preaches love while closing its doors to those who do not fit the mold.

The priests, the guardians of the faith, are not immune to the darkness within. Marriage, they say, would assuage the beast, but I question it. For the beast is not sated by the embrace of a spouse, but by the innocents it preys upon. Allowing priests to wed would not stop the rot within, for the rot is not in the vows of marriage, but in the hearts of men themselves. Allowing them to wed, I believe, would only shift the sands, not extinguish the flame.

Now, listen here, I haven't made any decision on this here matter yet. It's a right tight thing, it is. The church and the state, they're close enough that you can't tug 'em apart without causing a damn ruckus. And marriage, well, that's a tricky thing too. The government wants to define it, but they don't want to offend no one. Civil unions, that's what they call it. But is it really a marriage? It's just two people, joined together. Shouldn't the government leave it at that? And what about the constitution, they want to amend it to ban gay marriage. That's ridiculous, it is. The constitution's not a place for such a small cause, it ain't. It's not important enough to amend, don't you see? No, it isn't.

In the hardscrabble crucible of my upbringing, I was cradled in the tenets of a Christian household. Yet, the labyrinth of my mind is not so easily confined to such rigid beliefs. Homosexuality, to me, is a realm of gray areas, a shadowed expanse where the light of understanding is but a flickering candle. For I am acquainted with many who tread that path, and though I do not walk it myself, I do not deny them the freedom to do so.

The question of its legality, though, is a matter of state's rights. In this vast and varied land, where the winds of democracy and the tides of conservatism ebb and flow, it seems only right that each state should decide for itself whether to legalize this union. For what is a nation but a collection of sovereign parts, each with its own voice and will?

I stand firm in my belief that all should be afforded equality under the law, that no one should be denied the opportunities that others take for granted. It is a matter of justice, plain and simple. The federal government, with its distant and often capricious authority, should not impose its will upon the people. It is up to each state to decide what is best for its citizens, to hear their voices and act accordingly.

To suggest that a single president, no matter how long they may remain in office, can dictate the will of the entire nation is as absurd as claiming the sun rises only in Texas. This is a land of states, each with its own character, its own soul. It is not the business of one man or one party to decide what is right for all. Let the states decide, and let the people live with the consequences.

I am not here to argue, but to speak the truth as I see it. It is a truth that echoes through the silence of the wilderness, a truth that says, "Let each man and woman stand for themselves, and let each state stand for its own people."

Now, let me see here. That ain't to be taken as such a private affair, no sir. Everything you post on the internet, it's there for the world to see. It's like the wind, blowing where it may. And if the school officials should happen to stumble upon it, well, that's just the way it is.

Just like if you're posting about such things as drinking or smoking or what have you, you're asking for it. It's a public thing, and the school has a responsibility to ensure it's a safe place for all. If it's something that's gonna keep the kids safe, then by all means, they should be checking.

But if they're just going to snoop around, that's a different story. That's like sticking your nose where it ain't wanted. But if it's for the safety of the school, then I reckon it's all right.

It's a bit like when you're at the water's edge, and you see something there that might be harmful. You check it out, you see if it's safe. If it's not, you warn the others. That's what they're doing with these here internet things, checking if there's something harmful floating about.

Now, I ain't one to be surprised about how careless folks can be. It's like I once told a teacher of mine, "If you post something online, it's like you're painting it on the side of a building. You can't take it down, not once it's seen." And if a person's gotta go to college, they'd best remember that. They're gonna be judged on what they've done and said before, and it's gonna stay with 'em. That's just the way it is.

I mean, if something's leading to a safer place for the students, then fine, check it out. But if it's just for catching folks in trouble, that's a different matter. That's like hunting a man just for the sport of it. Not right, not at all.

And I say this: If parents drop off their kids at school, they expect a place of safety. And the school officials are just doing their job, making sure that place is safe. It's like the drills we used to do, back in high school. They were for the safety of all. And that's what they're doing here, making sure nothing bad happens. Like that tragic business at Columbine. That could have been prevented with just a bit of looking out.

So that's all I've got to say. That's all I can figure on.

Ah, the war. A wretched affair, it was. At first, I was all for it, you see. The specter of nine-eleven still lingered heavy, and I thought, perhaps, we should repay them in kind. But now, I'm not so sure. I reckon we were blinded by emotion, by the desire for vengeance. We stormed their lands, unprepared, unplanned. A fool's errand, it was.

I do believe the people there, they're caught in a cycle of violence, of chaos. They can't seem to turn it off, can't turn it toward anything else but each other. And we, we're just a distraction. A foreign force, trying to impose order on a land that's already been torn asunder. It's futile, I tell you. Like trying to tame a wild beast, you can only do so much before it turns on you.

We went in there seeking revenge, and we got it. But at what cost? The people there, they're not like us. Their war is not our war. They fight for different reasons, with different rules. And in the end, they'll be just as they were before we arrived. We can't change that.

President Bush, he was a man driven by emotion, by the desire to do something, anything. And the people, they wanted action. But it was a hasty decision, a decision made in the heat of the moment. We didn't have a plan, a strategy. We were like children with a toy, playing at war. And look where it's gotten us.

Now, I don't know. I don't know if we've made any progress. I see the rebuilding, but it's like trying to repair a house with a leaking roof. You can patch it up, but it'll still rain inside. We can't stay there forever, and once we leave, what then? Another cycle of violence, of chaos. It's a vicious circle, and we're just a part of it.

But enough of this. I've said my piece. The war, it's a mistake. A mistake we're all paying for.

In certain respects, the Catholic Church finds itself in need of change. Their eyes upon the world have grown stale, their hearts unyielding against the winds of change. The Church, once a beacon of faith for many, now finds itself losing its flock, for it clings too tightly to doctrines that the world has outgrown. Consider the matter of gay marriage, abortion, and birth control—issues where the Church's stance is as unyielding as the rock it claims to follow. These positions, though rooted in tradition, are seen as antiquated by many, and the Church's refusal to adapt has driven a wedge between itself and the people. The Church's opposition to abortion, for instance, is an affront to those who believe in a woman's right to choose. And the same can be said for its stance on same-sex marriage, which some view as a breach of their own hearts.

Now, I am not suggesting that the Church should abandon its core beliefs. Rather, I propose that it should consider a more compassionate and inclusive stance. The world outside the Church doors has shifted, and the Church must shift with it. The notion that priests are married to God is one that I, too, respect. Yet, I question why this union must be exclusive. Why not allow them to share their lives with those they love, as we all do? The Church's teachings on celibacy and the lack of female priests have long been a point of contention, and while I cannot guarantee that these changes would have prevented the scandals that have rocked the Church, I believe they would have mitigated some of the anger and disillusionment felt by the faithful.

The Church is a living thing, not a static monument. It must breathe, move, and adapt to survive. I urge the Church to consider these changes, to open its arms and its heart, and to become once again a beacon of hope and compassion for all people.

Well, I reckon I don't hold a bone to pick with the matter of gay marriage. I mean, it's not like I've given it a great deal of contemplation, mind you, but it just don't seem right to me. It's not as if they can choose to be that way, like it's a conscious decision. I believe that people, be they of a certain persuasion or not, shouldn't be held accountable for how they're born.

I've seen it said that a man and a woman can wed, but not two of the same sex. It seems a crooked sort of thinking to me. It's not like they choose their nature. I was born one way, another man might be born another. It seems a crime to hold them to account for their nature.

Now, the federal government, well, I don't see them having much say in the matter. It ain't like it involves the safety of our land, nor is it a question of morals. It just seems they're sticking their nose in where it ain't wanted. They have no right to interject in the lives of others, least of all those who are born as they are. It's not a sin to be what you are, to be born that way.

No, I reckon that's about all I have to say on the matter. It's a hard thing to put into words, but I hope it makes sense.

In the desolate expanse of these plains, there exists a conundrum, a divide as vast as the frontier itself. The matter of homosexual matrimony, a topic as intractable as the wilderness, is one that has emerged from the shadows of our past, demanding our attention. Why, then, should this union be denied?

The notion that such a pairing threatens the sanctity of the heterosexual union is as misguided as believing the sun sets in the east. They are but two aspects of the same coin, each face unique, yet each a valid expression of the human condition. The moral compass of one does not dictate the morality of another.

Consider the civil rights that accompany this union. Property taxes, healthcare, the right to visit a partner in sickness and health. To deny these to those who choose to love differently is as absurd as denying the right of passage to a river that flows in a different direction. The arguments against such a union are thin and devoid of substance, much like the echoes of a ghost town in the wind.

The fear of adoption and the supposed ill effects on society's children is as unfounded as the fear of the unknown. The children of homosexual couples are as likely to be influenced by their parents' choices as are the children of heterosexual couples. The science is clear: the factors that contribute to a successful relationship are the same, regardless of the gender of the participants. The community, too, should not be feared; it is as likely to be enriched as it is to be changed.

The federal government, with its vast reach and authority, should intervene in this matter. It is time for the amendment to be reversed, to be made to reflect the reality that love, in all its myriad forms, is a fundamental right. President Bush's stance on this matter is as divisive as his stance on abortion and stem cell research. It is a stance rooted in morality, but a morality as fluid and changeable as the seasons.

It is a pity that such a stance is often rooted in the religious beliefs of the few, rather than the cultural beliefs of the many. To let religious convictions dictate federal law is as hypocritical as it is undemocratic. It is a betrayal of the nation's founding principles, a rejection of the freedom of belief. To deny the right to marry based on the beliefs of one group is as un-American as it is unjust.

The notion that homosexuality is a psychological defect or a result of trauma is as baseless as it is harmful. It is a notion that is refuted by the very institutions that have conducted the research. To listen to the voices of the educated and the studied, rather than the whispers of the uninformed and the prejudiced, is the path to understanding.

This is not a battle between morality and immorality, but a battle between understanding and ignorance. It is a battle that, like the frontier, needs to be fought, and fought with courage, with conviction, and with a heart open to the possibility of change.

Well, first off, I tend to the pharmacy of a hospital come the summer months. It's a harsh world out there, but I've seen the cruel hand that some drugs have on the people. Now, I've heard it said that just because something is illegal, it must be beneficial. But I've seen the other side, too. The side where the law's writ is more a hindrance than a help. I say no, we should not make such things available to the masses. But, for the sake of those that need it, yes, for medicinal purposes, I say yes. The law's power is not absolute, not when it comes to the relief of suffering.

There are many a substance that's illegal, yet we use them in our pharmacies. Oxycodone, Vicodin, Percocet - controlled substances, yes, but beneficial, too. We can't deny their worth, no matter the taboo that surrounds them. Marijuana is no different. It's a complex one, I'll grant you that. But I say, we should embrace its beneficial properties, like we have with others. The key lies in the gradual integration, not the abrupt shattering of the law. Because, you see, we can't just remove the taboo around it. We must first remove the stigma, the fear, the poison that's been fed into the minds of the people.

It's a tough one. Marijuana, like alcohol, can be abused. But so can alcohol, and that doesn't make it something to be cast aside. The difference lies in the perception, the image. Heroin and cocaine, now there are substances we should be wary of. But marijuana, it's not like that. It's not as harmful, not in the way that others are. And if we can change that perception, if we can let go of the fear and embrace the truth, then perhaps we can use it responsibly. For medicinal purposes, yes. But also for the benefit of those who seek solace in its embrace.

Well, the church, she's a changin', ain't she? It's not as harsh as it once was. I reckon, when I was younger, it was Sundays and the prettiest dresses, matching shoes, too. I'd go to my private school and see all my pals there on weekends. It was somethin', it was.

Now, they've done a turn with the teen masses, cut 'em down to thirty minutes, casual clothes, folks comin' in straight from the beach - I've seen it all. I remember when I'd get dressed up for the mornin' mass, now it's jeans and khakis, even in the heat of summer. The biggest change, I'd say, is the people. The families, they run late, some folks dress casual. It's a different feel.

As for the rest, I don't claim to know the politics of the church, but I reckon that's about it.

Now, about them priests and their dealings with young'uns... well, I don't hold much water that they could've prevented it. There's men out there, married, and they still got it. It's in 'em, ain't it? Genetic, I reckon. You can't hide that away with a marriage. If they knew and covered it up, shame on 'em. But I don't believe in every case they did.

Other than that, I ain't got much to say.

Well, I reckon I was in agreement with the initial narrative, but I tell ya, everyone was still reeling from that September first, and I think we got ourselves into Iraq under false pretenses. There were plenty of lies spun to rope us in, connecting Saddam Hussein to Bin Laden and those September eleventh attacks. We were told of weapons of mass destruction, but those claims proved as hollow as a snowball in hell. It galled me to my core, that's for sure.

That Bush administration, well, they seemed to have no qualms about deceiving the American people. Even their own dog didn't believe 'em. Colin Powell, he's said as much himself, that he wasn't convinced by that UN presentation. That's more than just a misstep, that's a high crime. A man like that, lying to the people, it's an impeachable offense.

They had no respect for the Constitution, not since September eleventh. They came into office with war on their mind, and I reckon they were itching for a fight with Saddam Hussein, like a hound after a rabbit. It's all about the oil, if you ask me.

We can't just up and leave now, though. Withdrawal might just throw the country into chaos, and we've already seen enough death. The coalition of nations they're talking about, Syria and Saudi Arabia, well, that's just asking for more trouble. Iraq's sovereignty, it's hanging by a thread, and their government's about as effective as a wet blanket. That interim government, it's as fractured as a shattered mirror. And let's not forget that old scoundrel, al-Sadr. His party's got a good hold in the Parliament, and they're just one of many trying to grab power. It's a bloody mess, that's for sure.

It's just not right, I reckon, to make it legal or for any state to declare it so. It's a matter for the churches, damn it, seeing as the Constitution itself says plain and clear there's a separation between church and state.

It's written in stone, it is. Trying to enforce any kind of power over it would be defying what's already been laid down. I think them pushing for it to be illegal is like choosing one church's belief over another. Catholics, most of them, they're against it. It's not for the government to decide what the churches can and can't make illegal, is it?

Separation of church and state, that's been a cornerstone of this here constitution. Making an amendment about it, I reckon that would be wrong. It would be going against what's already been said and written. Plus, it'd be one of the only amendments used to restrict the people, not the government. It's just not right, damn it.

No, I don't believe the federal government or any other government should be involved in this. I reckon he's pushing for this amendment just because it's against his own beliefs as a Catholic. It's like he's showing a preference for one religion over another. It should be up to the churches to decide this, not the president or any other government official.

There ain't no real reason behind this amendment except for his personal views. It ain't gonna impact the economy or society in no way. If anything, it might have a better impact on society than leaving it the way it is. I reckon that's about all I got to say on the matter.

The war in Iraq, it began. A shroud of dishonesty, it was. The government, they said we'd find weapons of mass destruction, but none were found. They played on our grief, our outrage, our desire for vengeance. The invasion, 2003, it came.

I, I was against it. War, it's a cruel beast, and I've seen its handiwork. The Vietnam War, it echoes. We removed their government, but chaos followed. We didn't plan for it, not properly. We planted a democratic seed, like in Vietnam, but it wouldn't grow without sun and rain, without time.

Soldiers, they died. Too many. The government, they sang a different tune, said it'd be quick and clean. But it's been years, and still, we're there. Still, they're dying. We're training Iraqis, but it's slow. Democracy, it doesn't grow overnight, not even in our own land.

The oil, it's the root. That's why we're there. We control their resources, like we've always done. North Korea, it has weapons, and we do nothing. The government, they're not being truthful, not being thorough. They see dollar signs, not people.

The election, 2004, I thought about it. Bush, he started something. How can we abandon them now? We took their government, their way of life. But at what cost? American lives, they're precious. How much is too much?

It's a difficult decision, to leave. We must consider the future. But we must also consider the past, the present. The war, it's a monster, and it won't be easy to tame.

I hope for peace, but I doubt it. It's a long road, and it's just begun.

Let me see now, I reckon. I've always been in favor of that there gay marriage. Always have. It's a personal matter, a choice, you understand? Something that's a part of who a person is, not some stain on their soul. It ain't right to take away rights from folks for something they ain't got control over.

Now, don't get me wrong, I ain't saying it's all black and white. There's always a gray area, but I believe it's about love, pure and simple. I've seen it with my own eyes. In my neighborhood, there's a few couples, two or three, they're gay, ain't married 'cause they ain't allowed. But they're just like any other family, walkin' their dogs, livin' their lives. It ain't right what Bush was tryin' to do, playin' God with his interpretation of marriage.

It's a personal thing, not somethin' the government should have a hand in. It's between two people, not the whole nation. I've read it myself, it's somethin' in your brain, a predisposition. It ain't about the way you were raised, it's who you are. It's like the difference between the way a man and a woman are made. It's biology, not sociology.

And another thing, it's a private matter, not somethin' everyone needs to know about. If a man and a woman want to get hitched, they can just up and go to Las Vegas. But if two men or two women want to do the same, it's big news. It's like they're some kind of spectacle. It's their life, their choice. It's time we let them live it in peace.

No, it ain't right what's been goin' on. It's not right to deny folks their rights just because they're different. It's time we stand up for what's right.

Listen, I reckon you're aware of this, but let me spell it out for you. When you put something on the internet, you're making it public. As plain as day. No more hiding behind a wall of anonymity. I spoke on this very matter once, when I was an R.A. It's a fact of life, this internet business.

Now, why, you ask, should you be so cautious? Well, consider this: if you're putting out there that you're about to blow things up, or pull a trigger, someone's gonna take notice. And they'll do something about it. Because the internet, it's not just for you and your friends. It's a vast, open plain, where everybody and their dog can be watching.

I recall a time when something was overheard at school. Someone said something, and it was taken seriously. Why? Because the internet's no place for foolishness or jesting. It's a serious business, and what you say can have serious consequences. A sociology experiment gone wrong, maybe. Or perhaps something more dire.

Let me tell you, the internet's a double-edged sword. You put something out there, you're inviting the world to see it. If you don't want it seen, don't put it there. It's as simple as that. You can't dictate what people think or how they take things. You can't control their reactions.

Now, I ain't saying school officials should be snooping around, poking through Facebooks and Myspaces and all those social media contraptions. But if it's brought to their attention, that's a different ballgame. If there's danger, they gotta take it seriously. It's their duty.

You see, it's all about the line between what's private and what's public. And when it comes to the internet, that line gets mighty thin. So, think before you post. Because out there, in the wide-open internet, there's no hiding.

The conflict has stretched on for an ungodly amount of time, a stain upon the earth that seems to have lost its purpose. Initially, the cause was noble - to restore democracy in a land ravaged by tyranny. But the motives have long since been sullied, like the rain in a drought-stricken land. The wind of war has turned into a howling gale, and we are no longer the lighthouse but the storm itself.

The war began with a clear purpose, a beacon of righteousness. But like the moon's shadow on the earth, it has grown long and twisted, a shadow of its former self. The initial purpose, to liberate the oppressed, has been eclipsed by a new purpose, one of power and domination. It is as if we are now waging war for the sake of war, a beast that feeds on itself and its own.

The road to war was paved with the bones of men and the blood of nations. It was once a path of righteousness, to stand against a tyrant. But the path has become a maze, a labyrinth of deceit and greed. We are no longer the saviors we once believed ourselves to be. We are the storm that does not abate, the rain that does not cease.

The war has become a drain on our very existence, a leech that feeds upon our economy. The money meant for our own shores, for our own people, is being spent in a foreign land, a land that may never know the touch of democracy. It is a blight upon our land, a cancer that must be excised.

The time has come for the war to end. The officials of that land must stand on their own two feet, as we must stand on ours. We cannot be the crutch that props up nations, for it is a crutch that will lead us to our own downfall. The money spent upon this war is a debt that will never be repaid, a debt that will lead to our own ruin.

The war must end. It is a futile, endless struggle, a battle that can never be won. It is a war that is no longer worth fighting. It is a war that we must leave behind, like a ghost that haunts a empty house. The time has come to turn our backs on war, to turn our faces towards home.

Well, if I may, I'd like to inquire about this matter. I reckon it was averted due to someone uncannily stumbling upon certain information online. Now, I ain't one to insist on privacy, especially not on these here social sites like Myspace. If you put your life out there, for all the world to see, well, that's on you. It's like opening the gates to your own private sanctum. You might think you're sharing your life with friends, but you're also inviting the scrutiny of strangers. It's a double-edged sword, that's for sure. Now, I ain't got no Myspace myself, but I have me a Facebook. I've seen some sketchy characters out there, lurking in the shadows. I've seen how a person can dig up information like a coyote digging up a rabbit. They can find your name, talk to you, and before you know it, they're asking you to meet. I wouldn't do it, but some of my classmates, they ain't so careful. They don't know who they're talking to, or what they're giving away. It's a tricky business, all right. I only accept people I know, but you never know who might be watching. My roommate told me about her high school days, where they were banned from having Myspace. I reckon that's a bit harsh. I mean, how can they tell folks what they can't do? It ain't right, I tell you. It's a thorny issue, but I reckon it's one we all gotta navigate.

Damn, I reckon we got ourselves in quite the pickle here. The Iraq War, it's been a godforsaken mess from the get-go. I feel like a right son of a bitch talking about it, like I'm just riding the wave of them who were against it from day one. But, hell, it doesn't matter much now, does it? The whole world's seen that it was a bad idea, even our own troops over there think we should be pulling out sooner rather than later. It's a goddamn disaster, and pulling out ain't gonna be no easier.

I mean, look at the polls, will ya? Seventy-five, eighty percent of the world thinks it was a bad idea. Eighty percent of Iraqis, seventy percent of our own troops. It's a goddamn consensus. It's like trying to force a square peg into a round hole. We're trying to bring democracy to a place where it don't belong, and it ain't gonna work. Saddam was a bastard, sure, but we should've weighed the pros and cons before we stomped in there. It was like dancing with the devil, and now we're up to our eyeballs in quicksand.

I don't even know what to make of it all. I sure as hell ain't seen no good reason for us to stay any longer than we should. The administration? They're probably cooking up some hopeful ideas, but I ain't buying it. I've yet to hear a single legitimate reason for staying. If they want to do it gradually, over a year or two, I guess I could stomach it. But why should we stay now? Eighty percent of Iraqis want us gone, even a quarter of them want us to leave right now. These are the people we're trying to save, and they're telling us to fuck off. Maybe they know better than we do.

And if we leave, what then? We'll be the goddamn good guys, won't we? Not really. We'll never be the good guys in the Middle East, but at least we won't be the ones who fucked it all up. We'll be the ones who tried to do what was right. But, who's to say they won't see us as the devils we are? No matter what we do, they'll always hate us.

In these United States of ours, the specter of gender discrimination looms large. It cuts not merely along the lines of sex, but also carves deep into the very fabric of our societal tapestry. In the realm of labor, women, despite their qualifications, often find themselves trapped beneath an invisible glass ceiling, a relic of our collective past that shackles them to lesser positions. This is not to say that men are exempt; they too are not immune to the scourge of discrimination, be it in fashion, where the male figure is often overlooked, or in the domestic sphere, where the stay-at-home father is met with derision and scorn.

The path to change, however, is a labyrinth of slow progress. We have come far from the dark days of yore, but the march towards equality is a tortoise's pace. The women who claw their way to the upper echelons of business, and the men who choose to nurture their families rather than toil in the fields, are but the vanguard, their success stories slowly chipping away at the old notions that once dominated our minds.

Yet, change is also a double-edged sword. It must be wielded with care, lest it provoke a backlash. For every step forward, there are those who resist, who cling to the old ways, who see the new order as a threat to their own. It is a delicate dance, this progression, a slow ballet of acceptance and rejection. And so, we tread carefully, promoting the virtues of those who challenge the status quo, not by force, but by example. For in the end, it is not the loudest voice that wins, but the one that resonates, the one that touches the heart.

But discrimination, it seems, is not the sole domain of gender. It lurks in the shadows of our backgrounds, our upbringing, our speech. A man from the farm, his grammar rough, may find his intelligence undercut by his roots. His words, like his hands, bear the stigmata of his past, and some will find it difficult to see beyond the surface, to recognize the intellect within. The gendered gaze, then, is but one facet of a larger problem, one that afflicts us all.

Well, they didn't legalize it. They decriminalized it, knocked it down from a criminal offense to something more akin to a traffic ticket. You get cited, not booked and arrested. No more of that. And for young folks, the future ramifications are what they worry about. They don't go away, not completely. But there's a cost to all this, you know? Arresting, booking, housing, all of it. And the court dates, the public defenders, the judges, the state's attorney, it all adds up. Municipalities, especially those strapped for cash, they're not inclined to make that kind of concession, even if it'd free up a lot of money to spend on things they really need, like education, social programs, food for the homeless. I mean, it's not like we want marijuana to be everywhere, on every corner. And there are reasons why it shouldn't be. I don't know how I'd feel about it being like cigarettes, sold everywhere, smoked everywhere. It's still taboo in a lot of places. And it's not like either substance is completely harmless. Some people react differently, some people can handle it, some can't. It's not that simple. But I guess what I'm saying is, both have their own adverse effects. But I don't know.

I would say yes, for I have witnessed much that is traditional in these matters, as if time itself has little sway upon their actions. It is good to be rooted, to remain steadfast in ways that have been handed down through generations. Yet, it is also vital to be adaptable, to find the balance between the old and the new. In this, the Catholic Church finds itself in a peculiar state. The weekly gathering, the rituals, the strict adherence to doctrine - these are not without their merit. Yet, there is a coldness in the way they view those who do not conform to their teachings, a lack of tolerance for the beliefs of others. It seems hypocritical, for we are taught to love all, yet are told to shun those who do not share our faith. My father, an Episcopalian, was refused the sacraments because of his belief. This is not tolerance, but divisiveness. The doctrine speaks of love, yet the practice is steeped in the dated trappings of centuries past. It is a struggle to reconcile the two.

Yet, I do not believe this would necessarily influence the behavior of those who have fallen so gravely from grace. The molestation of children is not a matter of marital status, but a dark seed that has taken root in the soul. A priest's marriage would not change the nature of his transgressions, for his actions are not born of conjugal relations, but of his own twisted heart. Allowing priests to marry would not prevent such horrors, for they are not the product of marital status, but of the depravity of the individual. It is a different realm entirely.

I find myself at a crossroads, not yet firm in my stance on this contentious issue. The matter of church and state's separation, and the definition of marriage, is a labyrinth of thorny complexities that lie at the heart of our modern society. It is a tangled web, one that demands careful navigation to avoid offending those who walk its precarious path.

I am of the opinion that marriage, in its secular form, should be recognized as a civil union. After all, what is marriage but a union of two souls, regardless of their beliefs or the rituals that bind them? If we are to maintain a separation of church and state, then the government should not delve into the intricacies of marriage, be it religious or otherwise. It is a union, a contract between two people, and no more.

If each state were to arrive at a consensus, then by all means, let them push for federal recognition. Yet, amending the constitution to ban same-sex marriage is an absurdity. Such an amendment would be a stain on the sacred document we hold dear, a stain that would be remembered for generations to come. It is a cause that may be important to some, but it is not vital enough to warrant such a drastic measure. The constitution should not be amended for the sake of a single, albeit passionate, minority.

So, no, I cannot say that I support such an amendment. It goes against the very spirit of our nation, a spirit that was forged in the fires of diversity and tolerance.

In the crucible of my youth, I was forged in a home sanctified by the teachings of a certain faith. The matter of homosexuality, then, is a labyrinthine conundrum, for I have known many friends whose hearts are inclined in ways that differ from the norm. Though I may not align with their path, I contend that this should not be a matter of national import but a matter of state's discretion. The republic is a tapestry woven with various hues, each state a distinct thread, and no single leader should presume to dictate the moral fabric of all. The winds of change can shift with the election of a new president, and I see no benefit in this back and forth, in this political whirlwind. It is the state, the people, who will bear the consequences of their decision, not the transient figure at the helm of the nation. So let it be. Let each state decide. Let the people's will be done.

Well, now, I ain't got much to say on the matter, but let me spin this yarn real slow for ya.

Myspace, it's a public thing, ain't it? A bulletin board, so to speak. When you put somethin' out there, you're puttin' it out there for the world to see, not just the school officials. But if they're lookin' out for the students' safety, well, ain't that their job? To keep 'em safe, to make that school a better place? Now, if they catch wind of a student postin' somethin' they shouldn't be, well, that's their responsibility, ain't it? If it's about keepin' the school safe, I can't see the harm in that.

But, if they're just snoopin' 'round, tryin' to catch students in trouble, that's a different story. That's pryin' into kids' private business. But if it's to keep 'em safe, to save lives, well, that's somethin' else entirely. It's all about the bigger picture, you see?

I reckon it's a lot easier to express yourself writin' than talkin'. But the point is, it's a public thing. You post somethin' on there, you can't expect to get off scot-free. It's out there, for the world to see. And once it's out there, it's there forever. Can't unsee it, can't unread it. And if you're doin' somethin' you shouldn't be, well, that's gonna bite you in the ass sooner or later.

Now, I ain't sayin' they should go snoopin' around, just to catch students. But if they have somethin' that leads 'em to believe they need to make the school safer, well, then, I figure they're just doin' their job. It's all about makin' sure the kids are safe, ain't it? Just like we had drills for the terrorist attacks, to keep the school safe. That's what they were doin' here, just makin' sure nothin' bad happens, like what happened at Columbine.

That's about all I can say on the matter.

In the wake of the unforgiving storm that was Nine-Eleven, I was consumed by a fervor that burned like coal in the heart of a desert. I was for it - the war - not so much for the ideals it purported to uphold, but for the raw, unbridled emotion that gripped the nation. I was, in a sense, a man possessed, driven by a thirst for retribution that blurred the lines of reason.

At first, I envisioned a swift and decisive strike, a brutal retaliation that would leave its mark indelibly on those who had dared to strike at our shores. But the passage of time, and the grim realities of war, have tempered that initial ardor. I now see that our entry into this conflict was akin to a drunkard stumbling into a fight, not knowing what awaits him in the darkness beyond the door.

The people of that land, they are not like us. They are a people forged in the crucible of ancient hatreds and ancient wars. Their war is not a noble pursuit, but a dance of death, a grim ritual where the sacred and the profane are one and the same. They fight not for a better future, but for a past that has long since passed, a past that is as much their curse as it is their pride.

We went in blind, driven by anger and a desire for vengeance. We did not know the terrain, nor the minds of our foes. We were like a bull charging into a maze, expecting to find a clear path, only to find ourselves lost and alone. And all the while, the people of that land remained divided, their infighting a symphony of chaos that drowned out the cries of the few who would have welcomed us as allies.

Our presence there, it is a temporary salve on a wound that will not heal. It is a bandage over a festering infection. We are not the doctors who will heal this land, but merely the strangers arriving to tend to the dying. And in our haste, in our haste to act, we have forgotten the most basic tenet of war: to know thine enemy.

I no longer seek to change the hearts of those people. I have come to realize that they are not like us, and never will be. They are a people locked in a cycle of violence, a cycle as old as time itself. We cannot impose our order on their chaos, for it is a chaos that has defined them for generations.

The longer we stay, the more we become entangled in their fate. And for what? To impose our will upon a people who will never accept it? To create an order where there is only chaos? It is a fool's errand, a futile pursuit that will only lead to our own undoing.

I am no longer a man consumed by anger and a desire for vengeance. I am a man who has seen the absurdity of war, who has seen the futility of our efforts. I am a man who has come to realize that there are some battles that cannot be won, some wars that cannot be fought. And this is one of them.

In certain respects, the Catholic Church finds itself in need of change. Their eyes upon the world have grown stale, their hearts unyielding against the winds of change. The Church, once a beacon of faith for many, now finds itself losing its flock, for it clings too tightly to doctrines that the world has outgrown. Consider the matter of gay marriage, abortion, and birth control—issues where the Church's stance is as unyielding as the rock it claims to follow. These positions, though rooted in tradition, are seen as antiquated by many, and the Church's refusal to adapt has driven a wedge between itself and the people. The Church's opposition to abortion, for instance, is an affront to those who believe in a woman's right to choose. And the same can be said for its stance on same-sex marriage, which some view as a breach of their own hearts.

Now, I am not suggesting that the Church should abandon its core beliefs. Rather, I propose that it should consider a more compassionate and inclusive stance. The world outside the Church doors has shifted, and the Church must shift with it. The notion that priests are married to God is one that I, too, respect. Yet, I question why this union must be exclusive. Why not allow them to share their lives with those they love, as we all do? The Church's teachings on celibacy and the lack of female priests have long been a point of contention, and while I cannot guarantee that these changes would have prevented the scandals that have rocked the Church, I believe they would have mitigated some of the anger and disillusionment felt by the faithful.

The Church is a living thing, not a static monument. It must breathe, move, and adapt to survive. I urge the Church to consider these changes, to open its arms and its heart, and to become once again a beacon of hope and compassion for all people.

Well, I reckon I don't hold a bone to pick with the matter of gay marriage. I mean, it's not like I've given it a great deal of contemplation, mind you, but it just don't seem right to me. It's not as if they can choose to be that way, like it's a conscious decision. I believe that people, be they of a certain persuasion or not, shouldn't be held accountable for how they're born.

I've seen it said that a man and a woman can wed, but not two of the same sex. It seems a crooked sort of thinking to me. It's not like they choose their nature. I was born one way, another man might be born another. It seems a crime to hold them to account for their nature.

Now, the federal government, well, I don't see them having much say in the matter. It ain't like it involves the safety of our land, nor is it a question of morals. It just seems they're sticking their nose in where it ain't wanted. They have no right to interject in the lives of others, least of all those who are born as they are. It's not a sin to be what you are, to be born that way.

No, I reckon that's about all I have to say on the matter. It's a hard thing to put into words, but I hope it makes sense.

In the desolate expanse of these plains, there exists a conundrum, a divide as vast as the frontier itself. The matter of homosexual matrimony, a topic as intractable as the wilderness, is one that has emerged from the shadows of our past, demanding our attention. Why, then, should this union be denied?

The notion that such a pairing threatens the sanctity of the heterosexual union is as misguided as believing the sun sets in the east. They are but two aspects of the same coin, each face unique, yet each a valid expression of the human condition. The moral compass of one does not dictate the morality of another.

Consider the civil rights that accompany this union. Property taxes, healthcare, the right to visit a partner in sickness and health. To deny these to those who choose to love differently is as absurd as denying the right of passage to a river that flows in a different direction. The arguments against such a union are thin and devoid of substance, much like the echoes of a ghost town in the wind.

The fear of adoption and the supposed ill effects on society's children is as unfounded as the fear of the unknown. The children of homosexual couples are as likely to be influenced by their parents' choices as are the children of heterosexual couples. The science is clear: the factors that contribute to a successful relationship are the same, regardless of the gender of the participants. The community, too, should not be feared; it is as likely to be enriched as it is to be changed.

The federal government, with its vast reach and authority, should intervene in this matter. It is time for the amendment to be reversed, to be made to reflect the reality that love, in all its myriad forms, is a fundamental right. President Bush's stance on this matter is as divisive as his stance on abortion and stem cell research. It is a stance rooted in morality, but a morality as fluid and changeable as the seasons.

It is a pity that such a stance is often rooted in the religious beliefs of the few, rather than the cultural beliefs of the many. To let religious convictions dictate federal law is as hypocritical as it is undemocratic. It is a betrayal of the nation's founding principles, a rejection of the freedom of belief. To deny the right to marry based on the beliefs of one group is as un-American as it is unjust.

The notion that homosexuality is a psychological defect or a result of trauma is as baseless as it is harmful. It is a notion that is refuted by the very institutions that have conducted the research. To listen to the voices of the educated and the studied, rather than the whispers of the uninformed and the prejudiced, is the path to understanding.

This is not a battle between morality and immorality, but a battle between understanding and ignorance. It is a battle that, like the frontier, needs to be fought, and fought with courage, with conviction, and with a heart open to the possibility of change.

Well, first off, I tend to the pharmacy of a hospital come the summer months. It's a harsh world out there, but I've seen the cruel hand that some drugs have on the people. Now, I've heard it said that just because something is illegal, it must be beneficial. But I've seen the other side, too. The side where the law's writ is more a hindrance than a help. I say no, we should not make such things available to the masses. But, for the sake of those that need it, yes, for medicinal purposes, I say yes. The law's power is not absolute, not when it comes to the relief of suffering.

There are many a substance that's illegal, yet we use them in our pharmacies. Oxycodone, Vicodin, Percocet - controlled substances, yes, but beneficial, too. We can't deny their worth, no matter the taboo that surrounds them. Marijuana is no different. It's a complex one, I'll grant you that. But I say, we should embrace its beneficial properties, like we have with others. The key lies in the gradual integration, not the abrupt shattering of the law. Because, you see, we can't just remove the taboo around it. We must first remove the stigma, the fear, the poison that's been fed into the minds of the people.

It's a tough one. Marijuana, like alcohol, can be abused. But so can alcohol, and that doesn't make it something to be cast aside. The difference lies in the perception, the image. Heroin and cocaine, now there are substances we should be wary of. But marijuana, it's not like that. It's not as harmful, not in the way that others are. And if we can change that perception, if we can let go of the fear and embrace the truth, then perhaps we can use it responsibly. For medicinal purposes, yes. But also for the benefit of those who seek solace in its embrace.

Well, the church, she's a changin', ain't she? It's not as harsh as it once was. I reckon, when I was younger, it was Sundays and the prettiest dresses, matching shoes, too. I'd go to my private school and see all my pals there on weekends. It was somethin', it was.

Now, they've done a turn with the teen masses, cut 'em down to thirty minutes, casual clothes, folks comin' in straight from the beach - I've seen it all. I remember when I'd get dressed up for the mornin' mass, now it's jeans and khakis, even in the heat of summer. The biggest change, I'd say, is the people. The families, they run late, some folks dress casual. It's a different feel.

As for the rest, I don't claim to know the politics of the church, but I reckon that's about it.

Now, about them priests and their dealings with young'uns... well, I don't hold much water that they could've prevented it. There's men out there, married, and they still got it. It's in 'em, ain't it? Genetic, I reckon. You can't hide that away with a marriage. If they knew and covered it up, shame on 'em. But I don't believe in every case they did.

Other than that, I ain't got much to say.

Well, I reckon I was in agreement with the initial narrative, but I tell ya, everyone was still reeling from that September first, and I think we got ourselves into Iraq under false pretenses. There were plenty of lies spun to rope us in, connecting Saddam Hussein to Bin Laden and those September eleventh attacks. We were told of weapons of mass destruction, but those claims proved as hollow as a snowball in hell. It galled me to my core, that's for sure.

That Bush administration, well, they seemed to have no qualms about deceiving the American people. Even their own dog didn't believe 'em. Colin Powell, he's said as much himself, that he wasn't convinced by that UN presentation. That's more than just a misstep, that's a high crime. A man like that, lying to the people, it's an impeachable offense.

They had no respect for the Constitution, not since September eleventh. They came into office with war on their mind, and I reckon they were itching for a fight with Saddam Hussein, like a hound after a rabbit. It's all about the oil, if you ask me.

We can't just up and leave now, though. Withdrawal might just throw the country into chaos, and we've already seen enough death. The coalition of nations they're talking about, Syria and Saudi Arabia, well, that's just asking for more trouble. Iraq's sovereignty, it's hanging by a thread, and their government's about as effective as a wet blanket. That interim government, it's as fractured as a shattered mirror. And let's not forget that old scoundrel, al-Sadr. His party's got a good hold in the Parliament, and they're just one of many trying to grab power. It's a bloody mess, that's for sure.
