In these latter years, the Catholic Church finds itself beset by a peculiar malady, a waning of its flock. Some, in their wisdom, attribute this decline to an unwillingness to embrace the shifting tides of societal mores. The Church's stance on matters such as same-sex unions, abortion, and the contraception has grown increasingly rigid, a relic of a time past. This resistance to adapting to the modern world has, it seems, eroded their once-strong foundation of trust and belief.

Many a soul has turned their backs on the Church, finding their views on these contentious issues repugnant. It is not that the Church's beliefs should be discounted, but rather, that they should be tempered with an understanding of the world as it now is. The Church's unyielding stance on these matters has driven away those who hold differing opinions, leaving it a shrinking sanctuary for the faithful.

Consider the case of abortion. The Church's absolute condemnation of this practice leaves little room for those who grapple with its complexity. Similarly, the Church's stance on same-sex marriage has proven divisive, alienating those who seek acceptance and understanding. These are sensitive issues, and the Church's steadfastness has, in some instances, proven to be a barrier rather than a beacon of faith.

Moreover, the Church's refusal to allow women to serve as priests or priests to marry has been a point of contention. One might argue that these prohibitions are based on ancient doctrine, a devotion to an ideal of celibacy and chastity. Yet, in a world where dual commitments are the norm, the Church's stance appears anachronistic. While it is difficult to say with certainty that these changes would have prevented the Church's decline, it is clear that they have not been a panacea.

The Church, in its infinite wisdom, must now consider whether its beliefs can stand firm in a world that has changed irrevocably. It must decide if it will cling to its ancient principles, or if it will adapt, like the trees in the forest, bending to the wind, and still standing strong.

Well, I reckon I ain't never been one to turn my nose up at what folks have a mind to do with their own lives. Now, I ain't got much time for this whole gay marriage business, but I can tell you this - I don't believe it's no conscious decision. A man's born how he's born, and a woman's too. It ain't like they pick their lot in life. So, I don't see why we should be holding folks accountable for who they love. It's wrong to say that a man and a woman can get hitched, but two folks of the same sex can't. It don't sit right with me, that's all. I ain't given it much thought, mind you, but I'd say it's wrong for folks to say that. I don't believe the fed ought to have a say in it. It's not some matter of national security, nor is it a moral concern. It's just folks being who they are, and that's all. They shouldn't be punished for that. That's all I got to say on the matter.

In the vast expanse of human relations, it is my belief that the union of same-sex couples, much like the union of any two individuals, should be recognized and sanctioned by the laws that bind us. The argument that they pose a threat to the heteronormative family structure is as hollow as the echo of a gunshot in a vacant room. These unions are as diverse and intricate as the vast tapestry of human experience, each one a unique thread woven into the fabric of society.

The civil rights that pertain to these unions are not some peripheral concern, but a fundamental aspect of the human condition. Property taxes, healthcare, and the right to visit a partner in their hour of need—these are not mere niceties, but necessities that ensure the dignity and security of all individuals, regardless of their chosen path.

The concern about the influence of a same-sex couple on their children is a complex and evolving issue, much like the ever-shifting sands of the desert. The studies and data, though not yet conclusive, suggest that children of same-sex couples fare just as well as those of heterosexual couples. The psychological well-being of these children is not dictated by the sexual orientation of their parents, but rather by the love, care, and nurturing they receive.

The federal government, as the guardian of the union, should be the one to make gay marriage legal across all states. The amendment should not seek to exclude, but to include, to make the union of love and commitment available to all who seek it. The president, with his strong religious convictions, may have his own views, but the role of the government is not to legislate morality, but to uphold the rights and freedoms of its citizens.

The notion that gay people are psychologically damaged or that their orientation is a result of trauma or lack of parental attention is as outdated and offensive as the stories told around a campfire. The American Psychological Association has debunked these myths, yet the echoes of intolerance and ignorance linger like a mauvais air.

It is my fervent hope that we, as a society, will embrace the diversity of human experience and recognize the inherent worth of all individuals, regardless of their sexual orientation. It is not about denying the right to marry in a church, but about acknowledging the right to marry at all. To do otherwise is to perpetuate a segregation that is separate and unequal, a stain on the fabric of our nation. It is time to shed the shackles of ignorance and embrace the light of understanding.

Well, first off, I work in the hospital pharmacy this summer, and I've seen a thing or two about what's legal and what's not. Now, just because a substance is deemed illegal doesn't mean it's devoid of any redeeming qualities. Take, for instance, the likes of oxycodone, vicodin, and percocets. They're controlled substances, ain't they? Yet, we use them all the time because they serve a purpose. Now, I'm not saying we should throw open the gates to every street corner drug dealer, but I'm also not saying we should ignore the potential benefits of marijuana.

You see, the very fact that it's illegal paints a target on its back. It's a cultural taboo, a stigma that needs to be peeled away. I'm not saying it's the same as alcohol, mind you. Both have their dangers, but marijuana isn't the monster that some would have us believe. Heroin, cocaine, now those are substances that should be feared. But marijuana? It's not that bad, if used responsibly.

I'm not advocating a sweeping legalization, mind you. No, I think we should take things slow, gradually remove the stigma, and then we can talk about integrating it into society. First, we have to break down the taboo. Then, we can discuss regulation and responsible use. But until that happens, it's just a reactionary war on a leaf.

So, let's not judge a book by its cover. Let's look at the substance for what it is and not what society says it is. Because, in the end, it's just a plant. And plants, well, they don't care about societal norms. They just grow, year after year, waiting for us to notice them.

The church, it has shifted in the tide of time. It's not as stringent as it once was, not as it was when I was a youth. Sundays, Sundays were Sundays, Sundays were Sundays, Sundays were Sundays. I'd attend in my cute little dresses, matching shoes, matching purse, all the Sundays. I'd see my friends, my friends, my friends. We'd go, we'd go, we'd go. But now, now it's different. They've shortened the mass, cut it down to thirty minutes, and people, people, they dress more casually. During the summer, they come straight from the beach, in their beach clothes, and families, families, they're always running late. It's more casual, even the morning masses, where I used to dress up. Now, it's jeans and khakis. Khakis, they're fine, but it's just, it's just more casual.

As for the accusations against the priests, the pedophilia, I don't think it could have been prevented. There are men, men, men who are married, and they still, they still, they still. They have this attraction, this attraction, this attraction. It's in them. It's in them. It's in them. I think it's in their genetics. I don't think it's something they can change. They can try, they can try, they can try, but it usually comes out. The church, it's not their fault, not their fault, not their fault. It's in them, in them, in them.

Well, I reckon I was alright with the notion initially, but I'm certain we were still reeling from the 9/11 attacks. We went into Iraq with a devilish pretext, a cover, if you will. The Bush administration, they tied the Iraq war to Osama Bin Laden and claimed Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction, but we all know that was a lie, a damn lie. It's like they said, "If you can't make the truth stand on its own, make it stand on lies." It's been eating at me, the whole affair.

They lied to the American people, and they've yet to face up to it. Colin Powell, he's even said as much. He wasn't convinced by the evidence, not one bit. That's a crime, a damn crime. It's an impeachable offense, to lie to the people like that. And the Bush administration, they've been trampling on the Constitution, trying to trample it underfoot since 9/11. They came into office with one thing on their minds, and that was war.

I can't recall the name of the secretary of the treasury, but he said as much in his book, "They came with a blood vengeance against Saddam Hussein." It was all about settling old scores, and I reckon it was about the oil too. It's gone on long enough, but to pull out now, well, it'd be like a house of cards, crumbling, and more people would die.

The coalition they're talking about, Syria, Saudi Arabia, they'd try to restore order, but I'm not so sure. There's a chance it'd just cause more trouble. The interim government, it's like a house of cards too. The Parliament, it's not doing a damn thing. The Prime Minister, he's not in control, and Mugtada al-Sadr, his party's holding 20 seats. It's a mess, a damn mess.

I can't put it as polite as I'd like to.

I did, what? Mm-hmm. Just talking into it, I guess. Okay. Cool. Yeah, okay. Huh. Well, how do I feel about the War in Iraq? Let me see. Umm. I reckon it's a foolishness, like a fly that keeps buzzing where it ain't wanted. It wasn't declared, really, just a big show of might, to get back at those who we figured pulled the strings in '01. It's not a war, really, not like it should be. It's a mess, like the one that's been left in Iraq. We're there, trying to build democracy like a child trying to build a sandcastle, and then we're there for the oil, of course. But it's a waste, it's making everyone mad. If we stay, we'll have to help 'em build this democracy, and that takes time, more time than we got. If we leave, they'll be mad we messed it up, and they'll have to start over. It's a puzzle, a hard puzzle. I don't know, really, don't know much. But I think it should end, but I don't know how to make it end. It's a mess, a big mess. And the men, the sons and daughters, they're over there, and I can't just say I want it to end, not when they're there. But it's hard, it's hard to say we should stay when we can't change 'em, when they're not us. It's a long, long time, a long, long time.

Ah, well, I reckon it ain't right, making it legal or declare it as such by no state. The Constitution, it says clear as the river, separation of church and state. Trying to enforce any law on it, that'd be a defiance of what's already been laid down. And I figure it's up to the churches, not the government, to decide what's right and wrong.

Now, the people who want it made illegal, they're just choosing one church's belief over another. Most Catholics and Christians, they're against it, except for a few up in Boston. But I reckon it ain't the government's place to decide what's legal or not, according to the churches.

Separation of church and state, it's been a cornerstone of our Constitution. Amending it, that'd be wrong, contradictory to what's already been written. And it'd be one of the few amendments used to restrict the people, not the government. It's not right, I tell you.

No, I don't believe the federal government should be involved. The president's pushing for this amendment, it's just his personal beliefs, a Catholic's bias. It's up to the churches, not the government, to decide what's right or wrong.

It ain't gonna impact the economy or anything else. It might even have a better effect on society than it wouldn't. That's all I got to say.

In the cold, stark landscape of political discourse, the war in Iraq is a tale of shadows and shattering promises. To begin at the dawn of our entanglement, I posit that our government did not illuminate the full spectrum of truth in their rationale for invading Iraq. The dance of emotion and outrage, ignited by the 9/11 inferno, was a symphony of deception. The government played the strings of our hearts, weaving a narrative that tied the terrorist attacks to the sand and oil of Iraq, when in truth, the connection was but a thin, wavering thread.

I stand against war, particularly when it is wielded as a preemptive strike, a blade in the darkness. The war in Iraq is a grim echo of our past, a Vietnam redux, where the specter of communism and the ghost of democracy haunt the hallowed halls of power. A nation's government was torn from its throne, and in its absence, chaos reigned. The American government, in its hubris, believed they could supplant order from the void, yet they were unprepared for the tempest that would follow.

The ghosts of the fallen soldiers haunt the desert, their numbers a grim testament to the government's failure to foresee the consequences of their actions. The void of power, once a vacuum, now festers with insurgents, their defiance a bitter fruit of the government's hubris. The United States, a stranger in a foreign land, seeks to impose a democratic government, a task as Sisyphean as it is necessary. The government's blind optimism, a beacon of false hope, cast a shadow of deceit over the American people.

The war in Iraq is a crossroads of difficult decisions, where the weight of the past and the uncertainty of the future press down upon us. In the crucible of the 2004 election, I mulled over the choice, weighing the burden of abandoning our past actions against the cost of our continued presence. The specter of the Iraqis, left to the mercy of our handiwork, casts a long shadow over our conscience. How can we abandon them, the ones we displaced? Yet, the cost in American lives, a price too high, hangs heavy in the air.

The oil, the lifeblood of our economy, is a specter that looms over our actions. The weapons of mass destruction, once believed to be a smoking gun, now reduced to a hollow echo. The North Koreans, armed and untouched, a stark contrast to the Iraqis, left to the mercy of our whims. The government, it seems, is not thorough enough, not truthful enough in their decisions. The war in Iraq, a shadow war, a war of shadows and shattered promises.

I hope for peace, a beacon in the darkness, but I fear it is not to be. The war in Iraq, a tale of shadows and shattering promises, a testament to the hubris of power and the folly of war.

Well, I reckon I'm partial to the notion of gay marriage. Always have been. It's a personal preference, and it's been shown, more and more, that it's likely more biological than sociological. I can't see how anyone should lose rights over something they can't control, can't you? Seems unnatural, doesn't it?

Now, I'm not one to say that government has no part in it. I believe it should be a matter of personal choice, not something the state or the federal government should meddle in. It's not even a state-level issue, it's a personal one. It's about what you do in your own home, with your own household. I've seen it in my own neighborhood. Couples living together, raising families, just like anyone else. No one says a word, but they have the same rights as anyone else. Why should it be different just because they're not married?

And that goddamned Bush, trying to interpret marriage his own way. It's laughable, it is. He's got the audacity to claim it's his right to decide what's right and wrong. It's not his place. Not his call.

You know, they say it's in the brain, something we're born with. Not something that happens because of how you were raised. It's not about growing up with four sisters and no father making you different. It's not about that at all.

And let's talk about the sheer absurdity of it all. A man and a woman can elope to Vegas and no one bats an eye. But if two gay people want to get married, it's front page news. It's a goddamn circus. They should be left to their own devices, like any other couple. It's a private matter, not a public spectacle.

No, I don't think it should be any other way. It's damn well time we stopped treating it like a joke and started treating it like a right.

In this age of cyberspace, where all is laid bare for the world to see, one must tread lightly. The internet, a public forum par excellence, is a place where words and deeds alike become immutable. As a Resident Assistant, I have been witness to the consequences of such carelessness. When one puts words to the ether, they become a part of the collective consciousness, coloring the perceptions of others.

Consider, if you will, the path of the bulletin. You send a missive into the void, and it travels, unseen, until it reaches a mind. If that mind is attuned to the gravity of your words, they may act upon them. In our school, such a bulletin arrived, and though it was not explicitly the school's hand, it found its way to their ears.

The internet, my friends, is a double-edged blade. It grants access to the world, but it also gives the world access to you. What you post, you share. And what you share, you cannot unshare. The line between jest and sincerity is thin, and the consequences can be severe. The internet is a vast plain where truth and falsehood walk hand in hand, and it is up to each of us to distinguish between the two.

In this digital frontier, privacy is a delicate thing. It is granted to us, but it is also ours to guard. If you wish to keep your thoughts and deeds hidden, then keep them within yourself. But remember, the internet is a vast and hungry beast. It feeds on all that is offered, and it will not discriminate between the innocent and the guilty.

As for the school officials, they walk a fine line. They are tasked with the safety of all, a burden not to be taken lightly. They must be vigilant, but they must also be wise. They cannot monitor every whisper and every keystroke, for that is a path to tyranny. But when the whispers of danger reach their ears, they must act.

In this world of ones and zeros, we must be cautious. We must be mindful of what we say and what we share. For in the end, the internet is not a respecter of persons. It will take your words, your thoughts, and your very being, and lay them bare for all to see. And when it does, there is no turning back.

The war has been stretched out, twined with a purpose that once seemed noble, but now seems as fleeting as a pack of wild horses. The initial aim was to restore democracy in the land of tyrants, a just cause that, perhaps, was tainted by old scores, like the lingering echoes of bloodshed. The war, once a swift and decisive statement, has become a drawn-out affair, a monster that has devoured its own purpose, leaving behind a trail of confused motives and misguided pride.

The purpose we started with, to bring democracy to a land ruled by an iron fist, was a noble one. It was a just cause, a beacon in the dark times. But the war has become something else, a beast that feeds on itself, a victory that seems to be slipping through our fingers like sand. We are no longer fighting for a cause, but to prove our might, to keep the fire burning for the sake of it. We are mired in a war that has lost its way, a war that is draining our resources and our resolve.

The officials of the land we invaded are, perhaps, strong enough to stand on their own. The time has come for them to bear the weight of their own governance, to fend for themselves as they should. We have spent billions on this war, a war that has become a drain on our economy. Our own shores, our own people, are crying out for our attention, for the money that could be spent on roads, on schools, on healthcare. This war, this long, drawn-out war, is not a part of our future, but a blight upon it.

We must end this war. We must turn our gaze inward, towards our own land, our own people. We must address the wars we have on our own turf, the battles we must fight, the causes we must champion. The war in the foreign land, a war that has lost its cause, must end. The money spent on it must be spent here, on our own people, on our own land. It is our duty, our responsibility. It is long past time.

Could I trouble you for a moment to elucidate a query that's been plaguing me? Apparently, the matter was nipped in the bud by someone who, in their reckless quest for information, trawled the web and chanced upon certain details. Now, I must clarify, I do not deem this an affront to privacy. After all, if one were to post one's life on the internet, it is like placing it upon a public pedestal, visible to all who care to look. On platforms such as Myspace, to view another's profile, one must first be an accepted acquaintance, akin to a friend. However, this permission granted to certain individuals is akin to an invitation to the entirety of one's online existence. Thus, when one takes to the web, one must understand that their life, or at least its digital echo, is no longer private.

Yet, the task of monitoring every student's profile, lest they be up to no good, is a daunting one. It would be a task relegated to the sole discretion of a single individual, a modern-day watcher in the shadows. This raises questions of discrimination and unfairness, for who decides what constitutes 'bad' behavior? Is it the case that such monitoring is a mere precautionary measure, or is it a blanket surveillance, a modern-day panopticon? I am at a loss to say for certain.

As for myself, I do not partake in Myspace, but I am an adherent to Facebook, a platform I have found both beneficial and troubling. The internet, it seems, is a double-edged sword, offering connection and companionship, yet also exposing one's life to the prying eyes of strangers. I have seen firsthand the ease with which one's personal information can be gleaned, as a man on a television show demonstrated, using a girl's profile to coax her into a meeting, all within a matter of minutes. This has left me wary, yet I continue to use the platform, for it is a means of communication with friends. A delicate balance, it is, between openness and caution.

My roommate, in her high school days, mentioned a peculiar edict from her school officials: a ban on Myspace. I found this a curious dictate, for it seemed an infringement upon the students' right to privacy. I am not privy to the school's reasoning, but I cannot help but question their authority in such matters. It seems an attempt to control the uncontrollable, a futile endeavor.

Well, it's a fact, there's little else to talk about but the Iraq War, and it's not as if I've got much to add. I feel a certain unease, like a man trying to spit out bitter medicine, to speak on it. I wasn't always against it, but the fact remains it's an open wound, festering now more than ever. The world's consensus is clear, a chorus of agreement that the Iraq War was a mistake. Eighty percent of Iraqis, seventy percent of our troops, they all say it was a bad idea, and we should pull out. A disaster from the start, and pulling out will be just as bad, if not worse.

It's a quagmire, that's all there is to it. The Middle East, it's a land of contrasts, of stark divides. Our culture, their culture, it's like the chasm between two worlds, and we're trying to bridge it with democracy, when they've never asked for it. It's a foreign plant, a seed of discord sown in foreign soil. Saddam was a monster, no one can argue that, but we should've weighed the scales before we invaded. It's like stepping into quicksand, we're still sinking, and the more we move, the deeper we fall.

I don't claim to have all the answers, but I know this - we should leave. The administration, they've got their reasons, but I've yet to hear one compelling enough to keep us there. The people we're trying to help, they're telling us to leave. We should listen, ask them what they need, and then decide. It won't make us the good guys, but it'll be better than this. Better than where we stand now, in the mire of their conflict.

I reckon gender discrimination's still a persistent force within this land, even as we've made strides since the dark days of yore. It ain't just about the women folk; it's the specific fields and roles that we're talking about. Women, they've got a harder time, what with the glass ceiling that keeps them from the upper echelons of business. Society's been that way for so long that it's hard for some to accept a woman's worth and ability.

Take the fashion industry, for instance. A man in that line of work, folks'll look at him askance, thinking he don't know his ass from a hole in the ground. The same goes for a man stayin' at home, raisin' the young'uns. Society expects them to be out there, bringin' home the bacon, not tendin' to the hearth and home.

And it's not just about gender neither. Where you hail from, how you talk, it all plays a part in how they see you. A man from the farm, with a mouthful of vowels and a mind like a steel trap, he might find himself looked down upon, his intelligence questioned not by his deeds, but by his tongue.

Change, it's a slow beast, and society's set in its ways. But we're makin' progress, inch by slow inch. Women climbin' the corporate ladder, men stayin' at home, it's all becomin' more accepted. It's like, we're plantin' the seed, and given time, it'll grow.

Force it too fast, though, and folks'll resist. We've come a long way, and it's gonna take time. So, we keep on pushin', quietly, letin' the good qualities of these folks speak for themselves. And maybe, just maybe, we'll see the day when discrimination's but a memory.

The matter at hand seems to be the state's approach toward the substance, which has been decriminalized rather than legalized. This shift has demoted the offense from a criminal charge to a misdemeanor akin to a traffic violation, one that results in a citation rather than an arrest, trial, and confinement. The ramifications of such a charge, particularly concerning employment prospects, remain a concern. While the financial burden of apprehending, prosecuting, and detaining offenders is considerable, some argue that recalculating priorities might benefit the community, especially in places like Denver, where the populace is generally more accepting. However, the substance's potential to disrupt the social fabric and public health remains a contentious issue. Its widespread availability could mimic the situation with tobacco, where its sale and consumption are ubiquitous. Yet, given the current societal taboo, such a shift might feel jarring. Additionally, while both alcohol and marijuana impact motor skills and lifestyle adversely, individual reactions to substances vary greatly. Some adapt, while others do not. Nonetheless, the impact of these substances is profound and warrants careful consideration.

I would say yes, for the sake of argument. The world is rife with tradition, and there is comfort in the familiar, like a worn path through the forest. Yet, adaptability is a vibrant force that shapes the earth and all its creatures. The Catholics, they cling to their ancient rites and rituals, a testament to the power of custom. But there's a darkness that festers in the shadows of their doctrine. It's a rigid, unforgiving creed that doesn't tolerate the slightest deviation. They scorn those who don't conform, and those of differing faiths are met with the same scorn. My own parents, one a Catholic, the other an Episcopalian, were never blessed under the same roof by the Church. A love that transcends boundaries was met with the icy grip of intolerance. It's a bitter irony, isn't it? To preach love and acceptance, yet to shun those who don't fit the mold. The Church, it seems, is a house of contradictions, where doctrine and practice often collide. I've pondered the possibility of allowing priests to marry, but I shouldn't expect a simple solution to such a tangled web. Men who prey on the innocent will do so, regardless of vows taken. Marriage, it seems, is no panacea.

There is a clamor that doth echo through the halls of our nation as to the nature of this matter, and I find myself, a humble scribe, unable to fully grasp the threads of its tapestry. The separation of church and state, a tenuous balance, doth weave its way through this minefield of words, and the very definition of marriage, a sacrament as old as time itself, doth seem to dance on the precipice of offense.

I find myself in a disquieting place, for I know not whether to stand with one side or the other. Yet, I am drawn to the notion that marriage, be it rendered as a civil union, doth not require the imprimatur of the government. For, as it is, a union of two souls, it should stand apart from the conflicting clamor of the state.

The prospect of a constitutional amendment to ban gay marriage, I say, is as absurd as it is unnecessary. The constitution, a document of profound wisdom, should not be altered for the sake of a single cause, no matter how passionate the proponents. It is a weighty matter, to be sure, but not so weighty as to warrant such a change.

So, I say, let the states come to their own conclusions, and if there be a logical consensus, let it be pushed forth into the halls of Congress. But to amend the constitution for such a cause? Nay, it is not so important.

For, in the end, it is but a union of two souls, and that is enough.

I hail from a place where the word of God was held high, and thus, the matter of sodomites has always been a clouded issue for me. Many of my intimates in life have strayed from the path of the Lord and chosen this life, and yet, I hold no malice towards them. I do not argue with their choice, nor do I support the notion that such a life should be outlawed.

I believe that the laws governing our land should be decided by those who live under their weight, not by a single man in the nation's capital. This great country is as vast as it is diverse, with states of differing beliefs and values. A state that embraces love in all its forms should not be shackled by the decree of a distant power.

The President, in his hubris, has sought to impose his will on the entirety of this great nation. But I say to him, you cannot divine the will of all, for you do not walk the lands of each state nor share their burdens. It is the duty of the states to decide on such matters, for it is their people who will live with the consequences, not you.

I do not believe that the President should be the architect of our laws, nor should he be the arbiter of our morals. His term is but a fleeting moment in the grand tapestry of our nation's history. When he is gone, and a new soul takes his place at the helm, the laws will once again shift and change. It is the states that should guide us, not the President, for they are the bedrock upon which our union stands.

Now, a moment's pause. Let's see. The very notion of Myspace, that public forum for all to see and be seen. It's a bulletin board, plain and simple. If you post there, you're inviting the world into your thoughts. And if that world includes school officials, well, that's just the way it is. They have every right to see what you post, whether it's under the school's name or not. They can access it from their own homes, for the school's safety, for the students' safety. After all, they're responsible for that, aren't they? But if they're only there to catch students doing something wrong, that's a different story. That's an invasion. An affront to privacy. But if they're there to make the school safer, to prevent tragedy, then who can argue? The world has changed, and it's changed forever. Once something's on the internet, it's there to stay. You can't take it back. And if you post something foolish as a student, it might come back to haunt you. That's just the way it is. The world is watching, always watching. And if they're watching to keep you safe, well, that's something else entirely. They're not just watching; they're protecting. That's their job, isn't it? To make the school a safer place. To prevent another Columbine. That's what they're doing. They're doing their job. That's all.

War, it was. At first, I was consumed by its fire, by the smoldering embers of nineteen eleven. I yearned for vengeance, to wreak havoc upon those who had brought such chaos to our shores. But now, with the passage of time, I find myself disillusioned and disenchanted. We acted impulsively, driven by emotion, with no clear plan or strategy. It was a mistake, a grave one, for it has only served to create further discord and strife. The people of that land, they are not like us. Their wars are different, a savage dance of violence and destruction. They fight amongst themselves, and they will continue to do so, no matter our presence. We are outsiders, intruders, and our influence has done little to quell their internal strife. The initial impulse to strike back was understandable, but it was not justified. We should have sought a better way, a cooler head to guide us. We were driven by anger, by the desire for retribution, and it clouded our judgment. We invaded Iraq because we could not let the attack stand unanswered, but our methodology was flawed. The plan was vague, the goal unclear. We were like toddlers playing with matches, unaware of the inferno we were igniting. The people there, they are a people of violence, of hatred and division. They will not change, not with our help. We should have left them to their strife, to their internecine wars. We should have stepped back, let them burn themselves out, rather than fanning the flames with our presence. But we did not. We intervened, and now we are mired in a quagmire, unable to extricate ourselves. The longer we stay, the more we entrench ourselves in the conflict. We are not the saviors they need, nor are we the ones to change their way of life. We should have known better, should have been more cautious, more deliberate in our actions. But we were not. We were driven by emotion, by anger, and now we are stuck in a war that has no end in sight. It is time to leave, to withdraw our forces, to let the people of that land continue their own war, their own struggle. For they are not like us, and they will not change until they are ready. And in the end, perhaps, that is not our place to decide.

transformed_texts:
In these latter years, the Catholic Church finds itself beset by a peculiar malady, a waning of its flock. Some, in their wisdom, attribute this decline to an unwillingness to embrace the shifting tides of societal mores. The Church's stance on matters such as same-sex unions, abortion, and the contraception has grown increasingly rigid, a relic of a time past. This resistance to adapting to the modern world has, it seems, eroded their once-strong foundation of trust and belief.

Many a soul has turned their backs on the Church, finding their views on these contentious issues repugnant. It is not that the Church's beliefs should be discounted, but rather, that they should be tempered with an understanding of the world as it now is. The Church's unyielding stance on these matters has driven away those who hold differing opinions, leaving it a shrinking sanctuary for the faithful.

Consider the case of abortion. The Church's absolute condemnation of this practice leaves little room for those who grapple with its complexity. Similarly, the Church's stance on same-sex marriage has proven divisive, alienating those who seek acceptance and understanding. These are sensitive issues, and the Church's steadfastness has, in some instances, proven to be a barrier rather than a beacon of faith.

Moreover, the Church's refusal to allow women to serve as priests or priests to marry has been a point of contention. One might argue that these prohibitions are based on ancient doctrine, a devotion to an ideal of celibacy and chastity. Yet, in a world where dual commitments are the norm, the Church's stance appears anachronistic. While it is difficult to say with certainty that these changes would have prevented the Church's decline, it is clear that they have not been a panacea.

The Church, in its infinite wisdom, must now consider whether its beliefs can stand firm in a world that has changed irrevocably. It must decide if it will cling to its ancient principles, or if it will adapt, like the trees in the forest, bending to the wind, and still standing strong.

Well, I reckon I ain't never been one to turn my nose up at what folks have a mind to do with their own lives. Now, I ain't got much time for this whole gay marriage business, but I can tell you this - I don't believe it's no conscious decision. A man's born how he's born, and a woman's too. It ain't like they pick their lot in life. So, I don't see why we should be holding folks accountable for who they love. It's wrong to say that a man and a woman can get hitched, but two folks of the same sex can't. It don't sit right with me, that's all. I ain't given it much thought, mind you, but I'd say it's wrong for folks to say that. I don't believe the fed ought to have a say in it. It's not some matter of national security, nor is it a moral concern. It's just folks being who they are, and that's all. They shouldn't be punished for that. That's all I got to say on the matter.

In the vast expanse of human relations, it is my belief that the union of same-sex couples, much like the union of any two individuals, should be recognized and sanctioned by the laws that bind us. The argument that they pose a threat to the heteronormative family structure is as hollow as the echo of a gunshot in a vacant room. These unions are as diverse and intricate as the vast tapestry of human experience, each one a unique thread woven into the fabric of society.

The civil rights that pertain to these unions are not some peripheral concern, but a fundamental aspect of the human condition. Property taxes, healthcare, and the right to visit a partner in their hour of need—these are not mere niceties, but necessities that ensure the dignity and security of all individuals, regardless of their chosen path.

The concern about the influence of a same-sex couple on their children is a complex and evolving issue, much like the ever-shifting sands of the desert. The studies and data, though not yet conclusive, suggest that children of same-sex couples fare just as well as those of heterosexual couples. The psychological well-being of these children is not dictated by the sexual orientation of their parents, but rather by the love, care, and nurturing they receive.

The federal government, as the guardian of the union, should be the one to make gay marriage legal across all states. The amendment should not seek to exclude, but to include, to make the union of love and commitment available to all who seek it. The president, with his strong religious convictions, may have his own views, but the role of the government is not to legislate morality, but to uphold the rights and freedoms of its citizens.

The notion that gay people are psychologically damaged or that their orientation is a result of trauma or lack of parental attention is as outdated and offensive as the stories told around a campfire. The American Psychological Association has debunked these myths, yet the echoes of intolerance and ignorance linger like a mauvais air.

It is my fervent hope that we, as a society, will embrace the diversity of human experience and recognize the inherent worth of all individuals, regardless of their sexual orientation. It is not about denying the right to marry in a church, but about acknowledging the right to marry at all. To do otherwise is to perpetuate a segregation that is separate and unequal, a stain on the fabric of our nation. It is time to shed the shackles of ignorance and embrace the light of understanding.

Well, first off, I work in the hospital pharmacy this summer, and I've seen a thing or two about what's legal and what's not. Now, just because a substance is deemed illegal doesn't mean it's devoid of any redeeming qualities. Take, for instance, the likes of oxycodone, vicodin, and percocets. They're controlled substances, ain't they? Yet, we use them all the time because they serve a purpose. Now, I'm not saying we should throw open the gates to every street corner drug dealer, but I'm also not saying we should ignore the potential benefits of marijuana.

You see, the very fact that it's illegal paints a target on its back. It's a cultural taboo, a stigma that needs to be peeled away. I'm not saying it's the same as alcohol, mind you. Both have their dangers, but marijuana isn't the monster that some would have us believe. Heroin, cocaine, now those are substances that should be feared. But marijuana? It's not that bad, if used responsibly.

I'm not advocating a sweeping legalization, mind you. No, I think we should take things slow, gradually remove the stigma, and then we can talk about integrating it into society. First, we have to break down the taboo. Then, we can discuss regulation and responsible use. But until that happens, it's just a reactionary war on a leaf.

So, let's not judge a book by its cover. Let's look at the substance for what it is and not what society says it is. Because, in the end, it's just a plant. And plants, well, they don't care about societal norms. They just grow, year after year, waiting for us to notice them.

The church, it has shifted in the tide of time. It's not as stringent as it once was, not as it was when I was a youth. Sundays, Sundays were Sundays, Sundays were Sundays, Sundays were Sundays. I'd attend in my cute little dresses, matching shoes, matching purse, all the Sundays. I'd see my friends, my friends, my friends. We'd go, we'd go, we'd go. But now, now it's different. They've shortened the mass, cut it down to thirty minutes, and people, people, they dress more casually. During the summer, they come straight from the beach, in their beach clothes, and families, families, they're always running late. It's more casual, even the morning masses, where I used to dress up. Now, it's jeans and khakis. Khakis, they're fine, but it's just, it's just more casual.

As for the accusations against the priests, the pedophilia, I don't think it could have been prevented. There are men, men, men who are married, and they still, they still, they still. They have this attraction, this attraction, this attraction. It's in them. It's in them. It's in them. I think it's in their genetics. I don't think it's something they can change. They can try, they can try, they can try, but it usually comes out. The church, it's not their fault, not their fault, not their fault. It's in them, in them, in them.

Well, I reckon I was alright with the notion initially, but I'm certain we were still reeling from the 9/11 attacks. We went into Iraq with a devilish pretext, a cover, if you will. The Bush administration, they tied the Iraq war to Osama Bin Laden and claimed Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction, but we all know that was a lie, a damn lie. It's like they said, "If you can't make the truth stand on its own, make it stand on lies." It's been eating at me, the whole affair.

They lied to the American people, and they've yet to face up to it. Colin Powell, he's even said as much. He wasn't convinced by the evidence, not one bit. That's a crime, a damn crime. It's an impeachable offense, to lie to the people like that. And the Bush administration, they've been trampling on the Constitution, trying to trample it underfoot since 9/11. They came into office with one thing on their minds, and that was war.

I can't recall the name of the secretary of the treasury, but he said as much in his book, "They came with a blood vengeance against Saddam Hussein." It was all about settling old scores, and I reckon it was about the oil too. It's gone on long enough, but to pull out now, well, it'd be like a house of cards, crumbling, and more people would die.

The coalition they're talking about, Syria, Saudi Arabia, they'd try to restore order, but I'm not so sure. There's a chance it'd just cause more trouble. The interim government, it's like a house of cards too. The Parliament, it's not doing a damn thing. The Prime Minister, he's not in control, and Mugtada al-Sadr, his party's holding 20 seats. It's a mess, a damn mess.

I can't put it as polite as I'd like to.

I did, what? Mm-hmm. Just talking into it, I guess. Okay. Cool. Yeah, okay. Huh. Well, how do I feel about the War in Iraq? Let me see. Umm. I reckon it's a foolishness, like a fly that keeps buzzing where it ain't wanted. It wasn't declared, really, just a big show of might, to get back at those who we figured pulled the strings in '01. It's not a war, really, not like it should be. It's a mess, like the one that's been left in Iraq. We're there, trying to build democracy like a child trying to build a sandcastle, and then we're there for the oil, of course. But it's a waste, it's making everyone mad. If we stay, we'll have to help 'em build this democracy, and that takes time, more time than we got. If we leave, they'll be mad we messed it up, and they'll have to start over. It's a puzzle, a hard puzzle. I don't know, really, don't know much. But I think it should end, but I don't know how to make it end. It's a mess, a big mess. And the men, the sons and daughters, they're over there, and I can't just say I want it to end, not when they're there. But it's hard, it's hard to say we should stay when we can't change 'em, when they're not us. It's a long, long time, a long, long time.

Ah, well, I reckon it ain't right, making it legal or declare it as such by no state. The Constitution, it says clear as the river, separation of church and state. Trying to enforce any law on it, that'd be a defiance of what's already been laid down. And I figure it's up to the churches, not the government, to decide what's right and wrong.

Now, the people who want it made illegal, they're just choosing one church's belief over another. Most Catholics and Christians, they're against it, except for a few up in Boston. But I reckon it ain't the government's place to decide what's legal or not, according to the churches.

Separation of church and state, it's been a cornerstone of our Constitution. Amending it, that'd be wrong, contradictory to what's already been written. And it'd be one of the few amendments used to restrict the people, not the government. It's not right, I tell you.

No, I don't believe the federal government should be involved. The president's pushing for this amendment, it's just his personal beliefs, a Catholic's bias. It's up to the churches, not the government, to decide what's right or wrong.

It ain't gonna impact the economy or anything else. It might even have a better effect on society than it wouldn't. That's all I got to say.

In the cold, stark landscape of political discourse, the war in Iraq is a tale of shadows and shattering promises. To begin at the dawn of our entanglement, I posit that our government did not illuminate the full spectrum of truth in their rationale for invading Iraq. The dance of emotion and outrage, ignited by the 9/11 inferno, was a symphony of deception. The government played the strings of our hearts, weaving a narrative that tied the terrorist attacks to the sand and oil of Iraq, when in truth, the connection was but a thin, wavering thread.

I stand against war, particularly when it is wielded as a preemptive strike, a blade in the darkness. The war in Iraq is a grim echo of our past, a Vietnam redux, where the specter of communism and the ghost of democracy haunt the hallowed halls of power. A nation's government was torn from its throne, and in its absence, chaos reigned. The American government, in its hubris, believed they could supplant order from the void, yet they were unprepared for the tempest that would follow.

The ghosts of the fallen soldiers haunt the desert, their numbers a grim testament to the government's failure to foresee the consequences of their actions. The void of power, once a vacuum, now festers with insurgents, their defiance a bitter fruit of the government's hubris. The United States, a stranger in a foreign land, seeks to impose a democratic government, a task as Sisyphean as it is necessary. The government's blind optimism, a beacon of false hope, cast a shadow of deceit over the American people.

The war in Iraq is a crossroads of difficult decisions, where the weight of the past and the uncertainty of the future press down upon us. In the crucible of the 2004 election, I mulled over the choice, weighing the burden of abandoning our past actions against the cost of our continued presence. The specter of the Iraqis, left to the mercy of our handiwork, casts a long shadow over our conscience. How can we abandon them, the ones we displaced? Yet, the cost in American lives, a price too high, hangs heavy in the air.

The oil, the lifeblood of our economy, is a specter that looms over our actions. The weapons of mass destruction, once believed to be a smoking gun, now reduced to a hollow echo. The North Koreans, armed and untouched, a stark contrast to the Iraqis, left to the mercy of our whims. The government, it seems, is not thorough enough, not truthful enough in their decisions. The war in Iraq, a shadow war, a war of shadows and shattered promises.

I hope for peace, a beacon in the darkness, but I fear it is not to be. The war in Iraq, a tale of shadows and shattering promises, a testament to the hubris of power and the folly of war.

Well, I reckon I'm partial to the notion of gay marriage. Always have been. It's a personal preference, and it's been shown, more and more, that it's likely more biological than sociological. I can't see how anyone should lose rights over something they can't control, can't you? Seems unnatural, doesn't it?

Now, I'm not one to say that government has no part in it. I believe it should be a matter of personal choice, not something the state or the federal government should meddle in. It's not even a state-level issue, it's a personal one. It's about what you do in your own home, with your own household. I've seen it in my own neighborhood. Couples living together, raising families, just like anyone else. No one says a word, but they have the same rights as anyone else. Why should it be different just because they're not married?

And that goddamned Bush, trying to interpret marriage his own way. It's laughable, it is. He's got the audacity to claim it's his right to decide what's right and wrong. It's not his place. Not his call.

You know, they say it's in the brain, something we're born with. Not something that happens because of how you were raised. It's not about growing up with four sisters and no father making you different. It's not about that at all.

And let's talk about the sheer absurdity of it all. A man and a woman can elope to Vegas and no one bats an eye. But if two gay people want to get married, it's front page news. It's a goddamn circus. They should be left to their own devices, like any other couple. It's a private matter, not a public spectacle.

No, I don't think it should be any other way. It's damn well time we stopped treating it like a joke and started treating it like a right.

In this age of cyberspace, where all is laid bare for the world to see, one must tread lightly. The internet, a public forum par excellence, is a place where words and deeds alike become immutable. As a Resident Assistant, I have been witness to the consequences of such carelessness. When one puts words to the ether, they become a part of the collective consciousness, coloring the perceptions of others.

Consider, if you will, the path of the bulletin. You send a missive into the void, and it travels, unseen, until it reaches a mind. If that mind is attuned to the gravity of your words, they may act upon them. In our school, such a bulletin arrived, and though it was not explicitly the school's hand, it found its way to their ears.

The internet, my friends, is a double-edged blade. It grants access to the world, but it also gives the world access to you. What you post, you share. And what you share, you cannot unshare. The line between jest and sincerity is thin, and the consequences can be severe. The internet is a vast plain where truth and falsehood walk hand in hand, and it is up to each of us to distinguish between the two.

In this digital frontier, privacy is a delicate thing. It is granted to us, but it is also ours to guard. If you wish to keep your thoughts and deeds hidden, then keep them within yourself. But remember, the internet is a vast and hungry beast. It feeds on all that is offered, and it will not discriminate between the innocent and the guilty.

As for the school officials, they walk a fine line. They are tasked with the safety of all, a burden not to be taken lightly. They must be vigilant, but they must also be wise. They cannot monitor every whisper and every keystroke, for that is a path to tyranny. But when the whispers of danger reach their ears, they must act.

In this world of ones and zeros, we must be cautious. We must be mindful of what we say and what we share. For in the end, the internet is not a respecter of persons. It will take your words, your thoughts, and your very being, and lay them bare for all to see. And when it does, there is no turning back.

The war has been stretched out, twined with a purpose that once seemed noble, but now seems as fleeting as a pack of wild horses. The initial aim was to restore democracy in the land of tyrants, a just cause that, perhaps, was tainted by old scores, like the lingering echoes of bloodshed. The war, once a swift and decisive statement, has become a drawn-out affair, a monster that has devoured its own purpose, leaving behind a trail of confused motives and misguided pride.

The purpose we started with, to bring democracy to a land ruled by an iron fist, was a noble one. It was a just cause, a beacon in the dark times. But the war has become something else, a beast that feeds on itself, a victory that seems to be slipping through our fingers like sand. We are no longer fighting for a cause, but to prove our might, to keep the fire burning for the sake of it. We are mired in a war that has lost its way, a war that is draining our resources and our resolve.

The officials of the land we invaded are, perhaps, strong enough to stand on their own. The time has come for them to bear the weight of their own governance, to fend for themselves as they should. We have spent billions on this war, a war that has become a drain on our economy. Our own shores, our own people, are crying out for our attention, for the money that could be spent on roads, on schools, on healthcare. This war, this long, drawn-out war, is not a part of our future, but a blight upon it.

We must end this war. We must turn our gaze inward, towards our own land, our own people. We must address the wars we have on our own turf, the battles we must fight, the causes we must champion. The war in the foreign land, a war that has lost its cause, must end. The money spent on it must be spent here, on our own people, on our own land. It is our duty, our responsibility. It is long past time.

Could I trouble you for a moment to elucidate a query that's been plaguing me? Apparently, the matter was nipped in the bud by someone who, in their reckless quest for information, trawled the web and chanced upon certain details. Now, I must clarify, I do not deem this an affront to privacy. After all, if one were to post one's life on the internet, it is like placing it upon a public pedestal, visible to all who care to look. On platforms such as Myspace, to view another's profile, one must first be an accepted acquaintance, akin to a friend. However, this permission granted to certain individuals is akin to an invitation to the entirety of one's online existence. Thus, when one takes to the web, one must understand that their life, or at least its digital echo, is no longer private.

Yet, the task of monitoring every student's profile, lest they be up to no good, is a daunting one. It would be a task relegated to the sole discretion of a single individual, a modern-day watcher in the shadows. This raises questions of discrimination and unfairness, for who decides what constitutes 'bad' behavior? Is it the case that such monitoring is a mere precautionary measure, or is it a blanket surveillance, a modern-day panopticon? I am at a loss to say for certain.

As for myself, I do not partake in Myspace, but I am an adherent to Facebook, a platform I have found both beneficial and troubling. The internet, it seems, is a double-edged sword, offering connection and companionship, yet also exposing one's life to the prying eyes of strangers. I have seen firsthand the ease with which one's personal information can be gleaned, as a man on a television show demonstrated, using a girl's profile to coax her into a meeting, all within a matter of minutes. This has left me wary, yet I continue to use the platform, for it is a means of communication with friends. A delicate balance, it is, between openness and caution.

My roommate, in her high school days, mentioned a peculiar edict from her school officials: a ban on Myspace. I found this a curious dictate, for it seemed an infringement upon the students' right to privacy. I am not privy to the school's reasoning, but I cannot help but question their authority in such matters. It seems an attempt to control the uncontrollable, a futile endeavor.

Well, it's a fact, there's little else to talk about but the Iraq War, and it's not as if I've got much to add. I feel a certain unease, like a man trying to spit out bitter medicine, to speak on it. I wasn't always against it, but the fact remains it's an open wound, festering now more than ever. The world's consensus is clear, a chorus of agreement that the Iraq War was a mistake. Eighty percent of Iraqis, seventy percent of our troops, they all say it was a bad idea, and we should pull out. A disaster from the start, and pulling out will be just as bad, if not worse.

It's a quagmire, that's all there is to it. The Middle East, it's a land of contrasts, of stark divides. Our culture, their culture, it's like the chasm between two worlds, and we're trying to bridge it with democracy, when they've never asked for it. It's a foreign plant, a seed of discord sown in foreign soil. Saddam was a monster, no one can argue that, but we should've weighed the scales before we invaded. It's like stepping into quicksand, we're still sinking, and the more we move, the deeper we fall.

I don't claim to have all the answers, but I know this - we should leave. The administration, they've got their reasons, but I've yet to hear one compelling enough to keep us there. The people we're trying to help, they're telling us to leave. We should listen, ask them what they need, and then decide. It won't make us the good guys, but it'll be better than this. Better than where we stand now, in the mire of their conflict.

I reckon gender discrimination's still a persistent force within this land, even as we've made strides since the dark days of yore. It ain't just about the women folk; it's the specific fields and roles that we're talking about. Women, they've got a harder time, what with the glass ceiling that keeps them from the upper echelons of business. Society's been that way for so long that it's hard for some to accept a woman's worth and ability.

Take the fashion industry, for instance. A man in that line of work, folks'll look at him askance, thinking he don't know his ass from a hole in the ground. The same goes for a man stayin' at home, raisin' the young'uns. Society expects them to be out there, bringin' home the bacon, not tendin' to the hearth and home.

And it's not just about gender neither. Where you hail from, how you talk, it all plays a part in how they see you. A man from the farm, with a mouthful of vowels and a mind like a steel trap, he might find himself looked down upon, his intelligence questioned not by his deeds, but by his tongue.

Change, it's a slow beast, and society's set in its ways. But we're makin' progress, inch by slow inch. Women climbin' the corporate ladder, men stayin' at home, it's all becomin' more accepted. It's like, we're plantin' the seed, and given time, it'll grow.

Force it too fast, though, and folks'll resist. We've come a long way, and it's gonna take time. So, we keep on pushin', quietly, letin' the good qualities of these folks speak for themselves. And maybe, just maybe, we'll see the day when discrimination's but a memory.

The matter at hand seems to be the state's approach toward the substance, which has been decriminalized rather than legalized. This shift has demoted the offense from a criminal charge to a misdemeanor akin to a traffic violation, one that results in a citation rather than an arrest, trial, and confinement. The ramifications of such a charge, particularly concerning employment prospects, remain a concern. While the financial burden of apprehending, prosecuting, and detaining offenders is considerable, some argue that recalculating priorities might benefit the community, especially in places like Denver, where the populace is generally more accepting. However, the substance's potential to disrupt the social fabric and public health remains a contentious issue. Its widespread availability could mimic the situation with tobacco, where its sale and consumption are ubiquitous. Yet, given the current societal taboo, such a shift might feel jarring. Additionally, while both alcohol and marijuana impact motor skills and lifestyle adversely, individual reactions to substances vary greatly. Some adapt, while others do not. Nonetheless, the impact of these substances is profound and warrants careful consideration.

I would say yes, for the sake of argument. The world is rife with tradition, and there is comfort in the familiar, like a worn path through the forest. Yet, adaptability is a vibrant force that shapes the earth and all its creatures. The Catholics, they cling to their ancient rites and rituals, a testament to the power of custom. But there's a darkness that festers in the shadows of their doctrine. It's a rigid, unforgiving creed that doesn't tolerate the slightest deviation. They scorn those who don't conform, and those of differing faiths are met with the same scorn. My own parents, one a Catholic, the other an Episcopalian, were never blessed under the same roof by the Church. A love that transcends boundaries was met with the icy grip of intolerance. It's a bitter irony, isn't it? To preach love and acceptance, yet to shun those who don't fit the mold. The Church, it seems, is a house of contradictions, where doctrine and practice often collide. I've pondered the possibility of allowing priests to marry, but I shouldn't expect a simple solution to such a tangled web. Men who prey on the innocent will do so, regardless of vows taken. Marriage, it seems, is no panacea.

There is a clamor that doth echo through the halls of our nation as to the nature of this matter, and I find myself, a humble scribe, unable to fully grasp the threads of its tapestry. The separation of church and state, a tenuous balance, doth weave its way through this minefield of words, and the very definition of marriage, a sacrament as old as time itself, doth seem to dance on the precipice of offense.

I find myself in a disquieting place, for I know not whether to stand with one side or the other. Yet, I am drawn to the notion that marriage, be it rendered as a civil union, doth not require the imprimatur of the government. For, as it is, a union of two souls, it should stand apart from the conflicting clamor of the state.

The prospect of a constitutional amendment to ban gay marriage, I say, is as absurd as it is unnecessary. The constitution, a document of profound wisdom, should not be altered for the sake of a single cause, no matter how passionate the proponents. It is a weighty matter, to be sure, but not so weighty as to warrant such a change.

So, I say, let the states come to their own conclusions, and if there be a logical consensus, let it be pushed forth into the halls of Congress. But to amend the constitution for such a cause? Nay, it is not so important.

For, in the end, it is but a union of two souls, and that is enough.

I hail from a place where the word of God was held high, and thus, the matter of sodomites has always been a clouded issue for me. Many of my intimates in life have strayed from the path of the Lord and chosen this life, and yet, I hold no malice towards them. I do not argue with their choice, nor do I support the notion that such a life should be outlawed.

I believe that the laws governing our land should be decided by those who live under their weight, not by a single man in the nation's capital. This great country is as vast as it is diverse, with states of differing beliefs and values. A state that embraces love in all its forms should not be shackled by the decree of a distant power.

The President, in his hubris, has sought to impose his will on the entirety of this great nation. But I say to him, you cannot divine the will of all, for you do not walk the lands of each state nor share their burdens. It is the duty of the states to decide on such matters, for it is their people who will live with the consequences, not you.

I do not believe that the President should be the architect of our laws, nor should he be the arbiter of our morals. His term is but a fleeting moment in the grand tapestry of our nation's history. When he is gone, and a new soul takes his place at the helm, the laws will once again shift and change. It is the states that should guide us, not the President, for they are the bedrock upon which our union stands.

Now, a moment's pause. Let's see. The very notion of Myspace, that public forum for all to see and be seen. It's a bulletin board, plain and simple. If you post there, you're inviting the world into your thoughts. And if that world includes school officials, well, that's just the way it is. They have every right to see what you post, whether it's under the school's name or not. They can access it from their own homes, for the school's safety, for the students' safety. After all, they're responsible for that, aren't they? But if they're only there to catch students doing something wrong, that's a different story. That's an invasion. An affront to privacy. But if they're there to make the school safer, to prevent tragedy, then who can argue? The world has changed, and it's changed forever. Once something's on the internet, it's there to stay. You can't take it back. And if you post something foolish as a student, it might come back to haunt you. That's just the way it is. The world is watching, always watching. And if they're watching to keep you safe, well, that's something else entirely. They're not just watching; they're protecting. That's their job, isn't it? To make the school a safer place. To prevent another Columbine. That's what they're doing. They're doing their job. That's all.

War, it was. At first, I was consumed by its fire, by the smoldering embers of nineteen eleven. I yearned for vengeance, to wreak havoc upon those who had brought such chaos to our shores. But now, with the passage of time, I find myself disillusioned and disenchanted. We acted impulsively, driven by emotion, with no clear plan or strategy. It was a mistake, a grave one, for it has only served to create further discord and strife. The people of that land, they are not like us. Their wars are different, a savage dance of violence and destruction. They fight amongst themselves, and they will continue to do so, no matter our presence. We are outsiders, intruders, and our influence has done little to quell their internal strife. The initial impulse to strike back was understandable, but it was not justified. We should have sought a better way, a cooler head to guide us. We were driven by anger, by the desire for retribution, and it clouded our judgment. We invaded Iraq because we could not let the attack stand unanswered, but our methodology was flawed. The plan was vague, the goal unclear. We were like toddlers playing with matches, unaware of the inferno we were igniting. The people there, they are a people of violence, of hatred and division. They will not change, not with our help. We should have left them to their strife, to their internecine wars. We should have stepped back, let them burn themselves out, rather than fanning the flames with our presence. But we did not. We intervened, and now we are mired in a quagmire, unable to extricate ourselves. The longer we stay, the more we entrench ourselves in the conflict. We are not the saviors they need, nor are we the ones to change their way of life. We should have known better, should have been more cautious, more deliberate in our actions. But we were not. We were driven by emotion, by anger, and now we are stuck in a war that has no end in sight. It is time to leave, to withdraw our forces, to let the people of that land continue their own war, their own struggle. For they are not like us, and they will not change until they are ready. And in the end, perhaps, that is not our place to decide.

transformed_texts:
In these latter years, the Catholic Church finds itself beset by a peculiar malady, a waning of its flock. Some, in their wisdom, attribute this decline to an unwillingness to embrace the shifting tides of societal mores. The Church's stance on matters such as same-sex unions, abortion, and the contraception has grown increasingly rigid, a relic of a time past. This resistance to adapting to the modern world has, it seems, eroded their once-strong foundation of trust and belief.

Many a soul has turned their backs on the Church, finding their views on these contentious issues repugnant. It is not that the Church's beliefs should be discounted, but rather, that they should be tempered with an understanding of the world as it now is. The Church's unyielding stance on these matters has driven away those who hold differing opinions, leaving it a shrinking sanctuary for the faithful.

Consider the case of abortion. The Church's absolute condemnation of this practice leaves little room for those who grapple with its complexity. Similarly, the Church's stance on same-sex marriage has proven divisive, alienating those who seek acceptance and understanding. These are sensitive issues, and the Church's steadfastness has, in some instances, proven to be a barrier rather than a beacon of faith.

Moreover, the Church's refusal to allow women to serve as priests or priests to marry has been a point of contention. One might argue that these prohibitions are based on ancient doctrine, a devotion to an ideal of celibacy and chastity. Yet, in a world where dual commitments are the norm, the Church's stance appears anachronistic. While it is difficult to say with certainty that these changes would have prevented the Church's decline, it is clear that they have not been a panacea.

The Church, in its infinite wisdom, must now consider whether its beliefs can stand firm in a world that has changed irrevocably. It must decide if it will cling to its ancient principles, or if it will adapt, like the trees in the forest, bending to the wind, and still standing strong.

Well, I reckon I ain't never been one to turn my nose up at what folks have a mind to do with their own lives. Now, I ain't got much time for this whole gay marriage business, but I can tell you this - I don't believe it's no conscious decision. A man's born how he's born, and a woman's too. It ain't like they pick their lot in life. So, I don't see why we should be holding folks accountable for who they love. It's wrong to say that a man and a woman can get hitched, but two folks of the same sex can't. It don't sit right with me, that's all. I ain't given it much thought, mind you, but I'd say it's wrong for folks to say that. I don't believe the fed ought to have a say in it. It's not some matter of national security, nor is it a moral concern. It's just folks being who they are, and that's all. They shouldn't be punished for that. That's all I got to say on the matter.

In the vast expanse of human relations, it is my belief that the union of same-sex couples, much like the union of any two individuals, should be recognized and sanctioned by the laws that bind us. The argument that they pose a threat to the heteronormative family structure is as hollow as the echo of a gunshot in a vacant room. These unions are as diverse and intricate as the vast tapestry of human experience, each one a unique thread woven into the fabric of society.

The civil rights that pertain to these unions are not some peripheral concern, but a fundamental aspect of the human condition. Property taxes, healthcare, and the right to visit a partner in their hour of need—these are not mere niceties, but necessities that ensure the dignity and security of all individuals, regardless of their chosen path.

The concern about the influence of a same-sex couple on their children is a complex and evolving issue, much like the ever-shifting sands of the desert. The studies and data, though not yet conclusive, suggest that children of same-sex couples fare just as well as those of heterosexual couples. The psychological well-being of these children is not dictated by the sexual orientation of their parents, but rather by the love, care, and nurturing they receive.

The federal government, as the guardian of the union, should be the one to make gay marriage legal across all states. The amendment should not seek to exclude, but to include, to make the union of love and commitment available to all who seek it. The president, with his strong religious convictions, may have his own views, but the role of the government is not to legislate morality, but to uphold the rights and freedoms of its citizens.

The notion that gay people are psychologically damaged or that their orientation is a result of trauma or lack of parental attention is as outdated and offensive as the stories told around a campfire. The American Psychological Association has debunked these myths, yet the echoes of intolerance and ignorance linger like a mauvais air.

It is my fervent hope that we, as a society, will embrace the diversity of human experience and recognize the inherent worth of all individuals, regardless of their sexual orientation. It is not about denying the right to marry in a church, but about acknowledging the right to marry at all. To do otherwise is to perpetuate a segregation that is separate and unequal, a stain on the fabric of our nation. It is time to shed the shackles of ignorance and embrace the light of understanding.

Well, first off, I work in the hospital pharmacy this summer, and I've seen a thing or two about what's legal and what's not. Now, just because a substance is deemed illegal doesn't mean it's devoid of any redeeming qualities. Take, for instance, the likes of oxycodone, vicodin, and percocets. They're controlled substances, ain't they? Yet, we use them all the time because they serve a purpose. Now, I'm not saying we should throw open the gates to every street corner drug dealer, but I'm also not saying we should ignore the potential benefits of marijuana.

You see, the very fact that it's illegal paints a target on its back. It's a cultural taboo, a stigma that needs to be peeled away. I'm not saying it's the same as alcohol, mind you. Both have their dangers, but marijuana isn't the monster that some would have us believe. Heroin, cocaine, now those are substances that should be feared. But marijuana? It's not that bad, if used responsibly.

I'm not advocating a sweeping legalization, mind you. No, I think we should take things slow, gradually remove the stigma, and then we can talk about integrating it into society. First, we have to break down the taboo. Then, we can discuss regulation and responsible use. But until that happens, it's just a reactionary war on a leaf.

So, let's not judge a book by its cover. Let's look at the substance for what it is and not what society says it is. Because, in the end, it's just a plant. And plants, well, they don't care about societal norms. They just grow, year after year, waiting for us to notice them.

The church, it has shifted in the tide of time. It's not as stringent as it once was, not as it was when I was a youth. Sundays, Sundays were Sundays, Sundays were Sundays, Sundays were Sundays. I'd attend in my cute little dresses, matching shoes, matching purse, all the Sundays. I'd see my friends, my friends, my friends. We'd go, we'd go, we'd go. But now, now it's different. They've shortened the mass, cut it down to thirty minutes, and people, people, they dress more casually. During the summer, they come straight from the beach, in their beach clothes, and families, families, they're always running late. It's more casual, even the morning masses, where I used to dress up. Now, it's jeans and khakis. Khakis, they're fine, but it's just, it's just more casual.

They can try, they can try, they can try, but it usually comes out. The church, it's not their fault, not their fault, not their fault. It's in them, in them, in them.
